usage_sentences: The tightrope walker struggled to maintain his equilibrium.
The market reached a state of equilibrium where supply and demand were equal.
content.note: Equilibrium represents perfect balance, whether physical (like a seesaw) or abstract (like market forces). Maintaining it is crucial for stability in many systems.

content.meaning_en: The time or date (twice each year) at which the sun crosses the celestial equator, when day and night are of equal length.
usage_sentences: The spring equinox marks the beginning of spring in the Northern Hemisphere.
During the equinox, day and night are of approximately equal length.
content.note: Occurring twice annually, the equinox marks days when light and darkness are perfectly balanced globally. It symbolizes astronomical transitions between seasons, not just equal day/night.

content.meaning_en: Destroy completely; put an end to.
usage_sentences: Global efforts have been made to eradicate diseases like polio.
We must work together to eradicate poverty and hunger.
content.note: To eradicate implies complete annihilation, leaving no trace. Efforts like disease eradication aim for total elimination, a formidable and ambitious goal.

content.meaning_en: Excessive desire to work; workaholism.
usage_sentences: His ergomania was negatively impacting his health and family life.
Suffering from ergomania, he never took a day off.
content.note: Ergomania is an unhealthy obsession with work. While dedication is good, this compulsion can lead to burnout, stress, and neglecting personal well-being.

content.meaning_en: A person who loves to work.
usage_sentences: As a true ergophile, he was happiest when busy with a challenging project.
The company values ergophiles who show great dedication.
content.note: An ergophile genuinely enjoys working. Unlike ergomania, this isn't an unhealthy compulsion but a passionate appreciation for productive activity and professional engagement.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - Respect and admiration, typically for a person. (Verb) - Respect and admire.
usage_sentences: She is held in high esteem by all of her colleagues.
It is important to have good self-esteem.
content.note: Esteem is deep respect and admiration for someone's character or achievements. Self-esteem, conversely, is respect for oneself, crucial for mental well-being.
content.origin: From Old French 'estimer', from Latin 'aestimare' (to value, appraise).

content.meaning_en: Lasting or existing forever; without end.
usage_sentences: They swore their eternal love for one another.
The flame is a symbol of the eternal spirit of the nation.
content.note: Eternal signifies endlessness, transcending time. It contrasts with temporary or finite, evoking concepts of timelessness, often associated with spiritual or philosophical ideas.

content.meaning_en: Infinite or unending time.
usage_sentences: It felt like an eternity while we waited for the test results.
Some philosophies believe the soul lives on for all eternity.
content.note: Eternity is the state of unending time, a concept both profound and abstract. It represents perpetual existence, whether in a religious context or a philosophical one.

content.meaning_en: Moral principles that govern a person's behavior or the conducting of an activity.
usage_sentences: Doctors are bound by a strict code of professional ethics.
The company was criticized for its poor business ethics.
content.note: Ethics are fundamental moral guidelines shaping behavior and decisions. They provide a framework for distinguishing right from wrong, essential for personal integrity and societal harmony.

content.meaning_en: The study of the characteristics of various peoples and the differences and relationships between them.
usage_sentences: The professor of ethnology compared the marriage customs of different cultures.
Ethnology helps us understand the development of human societies.
content.note: Ethnology compares cultures and societies, studying their origins, distribution, and interrelationships. It reveals the vast tapestry of human diversity and shared patterns.

content.meaning_en: The study of the origin of words and the way in which their meanings have changed throughout history.
content.meaning_hi: व्युत्पत्ति विज्ञान/शब्दों की उत्पत्ति का अध्ययन
usage_sentences: The etymology of the word 'companion' relates to sharing bread with someone.
He has a keen interest in the etymology of English words.
content.note: Etymology explores the life history of words, tracking their evolution in form and sense over centuries. It's a fascinating insight into linguistic change and cultural shifts.

content.meaning_en: Remove (someone) from a place of danger to a safer place.
usage_sentences: Residents were ordered to evacuate their homes before the hurricane hit.
The building was evacuated after a bomb threat was received.
content.note: Evacuation is a critical safety measure, relocating individuals from immediate threats like natural disasters or conflict. It prioritizes human life and minimizes casualties.

content.meaning_en: Develop gradually, especially from a simple to a more complex form.
usage_sentences: Scientists believe that modern humans evolved from earlier primates.
The company's marketing strategy has evolved over the years.
content.note: To evolve means to undergo gradual change, often towards greater complexity or adaptation. This concept applies not only to biology but also to ideas, technologies, and societies.

content.meaning_en: Represent (something) as being larger, better, or worse than it really is.
usage_sentences: He tends to exaggerate the difficulty of his job.
Don't exaggerate; the fish you caught wasn't that big!
content.note: To exaggerate is to magnify reality, often for emphasis or humor. While sometimes harmless, persistent exaggeration can undermine credibility and distort truth.

content.meaning_en: A person who is taking an examination.
usage_sentences: The examinee must bring a photo ID to the test center.
Examinees were instructed to put their pens down when the time was up.
content.note: An examinee is the subject of an assessment, facing the pressure and challenge of demonstrating knowledge or skills. Their performance reflects their preparation and understanding.
content.origin: From the verb 'examine', derived from Latin 'examinare'.

content.meaning_en: A feeling of excitement, happiness, or elation.
usage_sentences: She felt a sense of exhilaration as she crossed the finish line.
The exhilarating ride on the roller coaster left them screaming with joy.
content.note: Exhilaration is an intense, uplifting joy, often linked to a sense of freedom or achievement. It's that thrilling rush of pure happiness, like reaching a mountain summit.

content.meaning_en: A poll of voters taken immediately after they have exited the polling stations.
usage_sentences: The initial exit polls suggest a close election.
News channels often broadcast the results of their exit polls as soon as voting ends.
content.note: An exit poll is a crucial tool for understanding immediate voter sentiment and predicting election outcomes before official results. It provides early insights into demographic voting patterns.

content.meaning_en: An area of wide extent of something, typically land, sea, or sky.
usage_sentences: The Sahara is a vast expanse of desert.
He gazed out at the endless expanse of the Pacific Ocean.
content.note: An expanse conveys a sense of vastness and open space, often inspiring awe or contemplation of scale. Think of an "expanse of desert" or the "ocean expanse."

content.meaning_en: A journey or voyage undertaken by a group of people with a particular purpose, especially that of exploration, research, or war.
usage_sentences: He joined a scientific expedition to the Amazon rainforest.
The expedition to climb Mount Everest was a great success.
content.note: More than just a trip, an expedition implies a challenging journey with a specific, often grand, objective, requiring careful planning and teamwork, like for exploration or research.

content.meaning_en: Force (someone) to leave a place, organization, or country.
usage_sentences: The student was expelled from school for repeated misbehavior.
The country decided to expel the foreign diplomat.
content.note: Expelling signifies a definitive removal due to misconduct or policy violation, carrying implications of authority asserting control. It's a forceful and formal exclusion.

content.meaning_en: (Of a document, authorization, or agreement) come to the end of the period of validity.
usage_sentences: My passport is going to expire next month.
The special offer will expire at midnight tonight.
content.note: This term highlights the finite nature of validity. When something expires, it loses its power or relevance, requiring renewal or replacement to remain effective or legally binding.

content.meaning_en: Put out (a fire or light).
usage_sentences: Firefighters worked for hours to extinguish the forest fire.
Please extinguish all cigarettes before entering the building.
content.note: Beyond just putting out a flame, to extinguish can metaphorically mean to suppress or eliminate a hope, feeling, or idea, bringing it to an end.

content.meaning_en: The practice of obtaining something, especially money, through force or threats.
usage_sentences: The shopkeeper was a victim of extortion by a local gang.
He was arrested and charged with extortion.
content.note: Extortion is not just theft; it exploits fear and coercion, compelling victims to surrender assets under duress. It's a crime of psychological manipulation and threat.
content.origin: From late Latin 'extortio(n-)', from 'extorquere' (to wrench out).

content.meaning_en: An outgoing, overtly expressive person.
usage_sentences: As an extrovert, she thrives in social situations and loves meeting new people.
His extrovert personality makes him a very effective salesperson.
content.note: Extroverts gain energy from social interaction and external stimuli, often characterized by enthusiasm and assertiveness. They thrive in group settings and outward expression.
content.origin: From German 'Extrovert', from Latin 'extra-' (outside) and 'vertere' (to turn).

content.meaning_en: An exact copy, especially of written or printed material.
usage_sentences: The museum displayed a high-quality facsimile of the original document.
You can send a facsimile of the contract to our office.
content.note: A facsimile is more than a copy; it's an identical reproduction preserving original details, vital for historical documents or artistic works. A 'fax' is short for facsimile.

content.meaning_en: A small, organized, dissenting group within a larger one, especially in politics.
usage_sentences: The political party was deeply divided by warring factions.
A small faction of the shareholders opposed the merger.
content.note: Factions often arise from differing ideologies or interests, creating internal division and potentially challenging the larger group's unity or direction. They can be powerful influencers.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Not genuine or real; counterfeit. (Noun) - A thing that is not genuine; a forgery or sham. (Verb) - Falsify; forge.
usage_sentences: The police warned about fake currency notes in circulation.
He was caught trying to use a fake ID to enter the club.
content.note: "Fake" encompasses deception in its various forms: as an imitation, an act of fabrication, or a deceptive object. Its purpose is always to mislead about authenticity.
content.origin: Origin uncertain, possibly from thieves' slang.

content.meaning_en: Capable of making mistakes or being erroneous.
usage_sentences: All human beings are fallible and can make mistakes.
Memory is fallible, so it's good to write things down.
content.note: To be fallible is to acknowledge inherent human imperfection. It suggests that errors are not just possible but part of the human condition, inviting humility and continuous learning.

content.meaning_en: The state of being untrue; lack of correspondence to fact or reality.
usage_sentences: The witness was accused of telling a deliberate falsehood in court.
He spread malicious falsehoods about his rival.
content.note: Falsehood represents a divergence from truth, ranging from innocent error to deliberate fabrication. It undermines trust and objective understanding, often with consequences.

content.meaning_en: Extreme scarcity of food.
usage_sentences: A prolonged drought led to a severe famine in the region.
Millions of people died during the great famine of the 19th century.
content.note: Famine is a catastrophic human condition, often exacerbated by conflict or natural disaster, leading to widespread starvation and societal breakdown. It demands urgent humanitarian intervention.

content.meaning_en: Very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail.
usage_sentences: He is very fastidious about keeping his house clean.
The fastidious editor checked every single comma in the manuscript.
content.note: Beyond just careful, a fastidious person exhibits a meticulous, almost obsessive, attention to detail and cleanliness, often striving for perfection in their standards.

content.meaning_en: Causing death.
usage_sentences: The driver sustained fatal injuries in the accident.
Delaying the decision could have a fatal impact on the project.
content.note: "Fatal" is definitive; it signifies an outcome that inevitably leads to death. It implies finality and the irreversible nature of an injury, disease, or event.

content.meaning_en: The development of events beyond a person's control, regarded as predetermined by a supernatural power.
usage_sentences: He felt that it was his fate to become a doctor.
They believed their meeting was a matter of fate.
content.note: Fate implies a grand, unfolding design, where individual choices might seem secondary to a predetermined destiny. It raises philosophical questions about free will versus determinism.
content.origin: From Latin 'fatum', meaning 'that which has been spoken'.

content.meaning_en: The animals of a particular region, habitat, or geological period.
usage_sentences: The book documents the diverse flora and fauna of the Amazon rainforest.
Australia is known for its unique and unusual fauna.
content.note: "Fauna" refers collectively to all animal life in an ecosystem or region. It's often paired with "flora" to describe the complete biological makeup of an environment.
content.origin: From 'Fauna', the name of a Roman goddess of earth and fertility.

content.meaning_en: Possible and practical to do easily or conveniently.
usage_sentences: We need to find a feasible solution to this problem.
Building a new airport is not financially feasible at the moment.
content.note: A feasible plan isn't just possible; it's also practical and achievable without undue difficulty or resources. It implies realistic execution and viable outcomes for a project.

content.meaning_en: Congratulate (someone).
usage_sentences: The principal will felicitate the top-ranking students at the ceremony.
We would like to felicitate you on your remarkable achievement.
content.note: "Felicitate" is a formal way to express joy and congratulations, often used in celebratory or official contexts to acknowledge someone's success or happiness.

content.meaning_en: Present participle of felicitate (congratulating).
usage_sentences: The crowd was busy felicitating the winning team.
He sent a card felicitating the new parents.
content.note: Felicitating denotes the ongoing act of congratulating, celebrating, or expressing joy and good wishes towards someone for an achievement or happy occasion.

content.meaning_en: An advocate of women's rights on the grounds of political, social, and economic equality to men.
usage_sentences: She is a prominent feminist who campaigns for gender equality.
The feminist movement has brought about significant social changes.
content.note: Feminism champions equality across all genders, challenging systemic biases and advocating for social justice, not merely superiority but equitable opportunity and rights for women.

content.meaning_en: Relating to a festival or feast; festive.
usage_sentences: The town was decorated in a festal manner for the annual celebration.
A festal mood pervaded the entire city during the holidays.
content.note: "Festal" evokes an atmosphere of joyous celebration, often associated with religious holidays or significant cultural events, marked by merriment, feasting, and community spirit.

content.meaning_en: Literature in the form of prose, especially novels and short stories, that describes imaginary events and people.
usage_sentences: She enjoys reading historical fiction.
The story is a work of fiction and any resemblance to real people is coincidental.
content.note: Fiction allows us to explore imagined worlds and characters, offering insights into human nature and society through narrative, often reflecting deeper truths than factual accounts.

content.meaning_en: Not real or true, being imaginary or having been fabricated.
usage_sentences: All the characters in the novel are fictitious.
He gave a fictitious name to the police officer.
content.note: "Fictitious" specifically denotes something invented or made up, existing only in imagination or as a deliberate fabrication. It contrasts sharply with factual reality.
content.origin: From late Latin 'ficticius', from 'fingere' (to form, contrive).

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Solid, strong, and unyielding. (Noun) - A business partnership or company. (Verb) - Make or become firm.
usage_sentences: You need a firm mattress for good back support.
He works for a major law firm in the city.
content.note: This word uniquely describes both physical solidity ("firm ground") and steadfastness of character or resolve ("firm decision"), as well as a business entity, illustrating its versatility.

content.meaning_en: A mark, blemish, or other imperfection which mars a substance or surface.
usage_sentences: There was a small flaw in the diamond that reduced its value.
Despite his many talents, his main flaw is arrogance.
content.note: A flaw is an imperfection that detracts from perfection, whether physical or metaphorical. It reveals vulnerability or a defect, sometimes hidden, sometimes obvious, impacting quality or integrity.

content.meaning_en: Capable of bending easily without breaking.
usage_sentences: Gymnasts and dancers need to be extremely flexible.
My work hours are flexible, so I can start and finish early.
content.note: Flexibility is not just physical; it describes adaptability and openness to change in ideas, plans, or attitudes, essential for navigating complex situations and fostering resilience.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A number of birds of one kind feeding, resting, or traveling together. (Verb) - Congregate or flock together.
usage_sentences: A flock of sheep was grazing in the field.
Tourists flock to the city every summer to see the sights.
content.note: "Flock" highlights collective behavior, often implying safety in numbers or a shared direction. People can also "flock" to a popular event, emphasizing group movement.

content.meaning_en: The plants of a particular region, habitat, or geological period.
usage_sentences: The book provides a detailed guide to the local flora.
Scientists are studying the unique flora of the island.
content.note: "Flora" represents the entire plant life of an area, often studied alongside "fauna" to understand ecosystem biodiversity, environmental health, and botanical richness.
content.origin: From 'Flora', the name of the Roman goddess of flowers.

content.meaning_en: A person who sells flowers and ornamental plants.
usage_sentences: I ordered a beautiful bouquet from the local florist.
She decided to become a florist because of her love for flowers.
content.note: A florist crafts emotions and messages through flowers, creating arrangements for celebrations, sympathy, or everyday beauty. They are artists of natural, ephemeral expressions.

content.meaning_en: The action or process of flowing or flowing out.
usage_sentences: The country's political situation is currently in a state of flux.
The technology industry is in constant flux, with new innovations every day.
content.note: "Flux" describes a state of continuous change or instability, where things are constantly in motion or transition, rather than fixed. It's a dynamic and often unpredictable state.

content.meaning_en: The destruction of a fetus.
usage_sentences: Female foeticide is a major social issue in some parts of the world.
Strict laws have been enacted to prevent foeticide.
content.note: Foeticide refers to the deliberate act of ending a pregnancy by destroying the fetus, often raising profound ethical, legal, and moral debates in society.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - People in general. (Adjective) - Of or relating to the traditional art or culture of a community or nation.
usage_sentences: The festival featured traditional folk music and dancing.
The old folks in the village have many stories to tell.
content.note: "Folk" evokes a sense of shared heritage and community, encompassing traditions, stories, and art passed down through generations, representing collective identity and cultural roots.
content.origin: From Old English 'folc', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A traditional story passed down orally.
usage_sentences: Every culture has its own unique collection of folktales.
The children gathered around to listen to an old folktale.
content.note: Folktales are cultural mirrors, reflecting values, fears, and wisdom across generations, often featuring moral lessons, mythical creatures, or ordinary heroes, preserving oral traditions.

content.meaning_en: Go or come after (a person or thing proceeding ahead); move or travel behind.
usage_sentences: The little ducklings follow their mother everywhere she goes.
Please follow the instructions carefully to assemble the furniture.
content.note: Beyond physical movement, "follow" implies adherence to rules, understanding an argument, or being a devoted supporter. It speaks to alignment, pursuit, or comprehension.
content.origin: From Old English 'folgian', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: Relating to or denoting the application of scientific methods and techniques to the investigation of crime.
usage_sentences: The forensic team collected fingerprints and DNA evidence from the crime scene.
Forensic science played a crucial role in solving the case.
content.note: Forensic science bridges law and science, using precise techniques to uncover objective evidence and reconstruct events, bringing clarity to complex criminal investigations and justice.
content.origin: From Latin 'forensis' (of the forum, public), from 'forum'.

content.meaning_en: The remains or impression of a prehistoric plant or animal embedded in rock and preserved in petrified form.
usage_sentences: Paleontologists discovered the fossil of a new dinosaur species.
Fossil fuels like coal and oil are formed from ancient organic matter.
content.note: Fossils are windows into Earth's deep past, offering tangible evidence of ancient life and environments, crucial for understanding evolution and geological history over millennia.

content.meaning_en: Easily broken or damaged; delicate.
usage_sentences: Please handle this fragile antique vase with extreme care.
The peace agreement between the two countries is still very fragile.
content.note: "Fragile" conveys vulnerability, not just physical susceptibility to breaking, but also emotional delicacy or the precariousness of a situation. Handle with care and understanding.

content.meaning_en: The killing of one's brother or sister.
usage_sentences: The story of Cain and Abel is a biblical tale of fratricide.
The civil war was a tragedy of fratricide, pitting brother against brother.
content.note: Fratricide is a specific and particularly tragic act, symbolizing profound betrayal and the destruction of familial bonds. It carries intense historical and literary significance.

content.meaning_en: Wrongful or criminal deception intended to result in financial or personal gain.
usage_sentences: He was found guilty of committing tax fraud.
The company was involved in a massive accounting fraud.
content.note: Fraud involves intentional misrepresentation for illicit gain, exploiting trust or ignorance. It undermines economic systems and societal integrity through deliberate deceit.

content.meaning_en: The feeling of being upset or annoyed as a result of being unable to change or achieve something.
usage_sentences: She screamed out in frustration when her computer crashed again.
His inability to solve the puzzle was a source of great frustration.
content.note: Frustration stems from thwarted goals or perceived obstacles, manifesting as emotional distress. It can be a powerful motivator for change or, conversely, lead to resignation.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who has escaped from captivity or is in hiding, especially to avoid arrest or prosecution. (Adjective) - Having escaped or run away.
usage_sentences: The police launched a massive manhunt for the fugitive.
He lived as a fugitive for ten years before being captured.
content.note: A fugitive lives in a state of constant evasion, often on the run from justice, highlighting themes of pursuit, freedom, and the consequences of past actions.

content.meaning_en: A person or event organized for the purpose of raising money for a cause or charity.
usage_sentences: The school organized a fundraiser to build a new library.
She is an experienced fundraiser for several non-profit organizations.
content.note: Fundraisers mobilize collective effort and generosity to support vital causes, transforming individual contributions into impactful communal aid and progress for charitable missions.

content.meaning_en: A member of a large group of eukaryotic organisms that includes microorganisms (such as yeasts and molds) as well as the more familiar mushrooms and toadstools.
usage_sentences: Mushrooms and molds are both types of fungus.
The damp conditions in the basement led to the growth of fungus on the walls.
content.note: Fungi are crucial decomposers, recycling nutrients in ecosystems, and have diverse roles from food production (yeast) to medicine (penicillin). They are neither plant nor animal.

content.meaning_en: The thick coat of soft hair on the body of a mammal.
usage_sentences: The cat has thick, soft fur that is pleasant to touch.
The use of animal fur in fashion is a controversial topic.
content.note: Fur provides insulation and camouflage for mammals, vital for survival in diverse climates. It represents natural protection and often evokes softness and warmth.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - Excessive concern over something unimportant. (Verb) - Show unnecessary or excessive concern about something.
usage_sentences: Don't make such a fuss over a little spilled milk.
There was a lot of fuss and excitement when the movie star arrived.
content.note: "Fuss" implies disproportionate worry or attention given to minor matters, often leading to unnecessary commotion or complaint. It suggests a lack of perspective or composure.

content.meaning_en: (Of a person or their behavior) brave; heroic.
usage_sentences: The gallant soldier was awarded a medal for his bravery.
He made a gallant effort to rescue the people from the burning building.
content.note: Gallantry describes a noble courage, often combined with chivalry and courtesy, particularly in challenging or dangerous situations. It embodies selfless heroism and honorable conduct.
content.origin: From Old French 'galant', from 'galer' (to rejoice, make merry).

content.meaning_en: An award bestowed for gallant or heroic acts.
usage_sentences: He received the nation's highest gallantry award for his actions in the war.
Several soldiers were presented with gallantry awards at the ceremony.
content.note: Gallantry awards honor exceptional bravery and self-sacrifice, recognizing individuals who demonstrate extraordinary valor, particularly in military or civil service contexts, inspiring respect.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Affecting or concerning all or most people, places, or things; widespread. (Noun) - A commander of an army, or an army officer of very high rank.
usage_sentences: The general consensus is that the new policy will be beneficial.
He was promoted to the rank of General in the army.
content.note: "General" uniquely describes both broad applicability ("general knowledge") and a specific, high-ranking military leadership position, denoting wide scope or ultimate command authority.

content.meaning_en: The origin or mode of formation of something.
usage_sentences: The book describes the genesis of the American Revolution.
The project had its genesis in a conversation between two friends.
content.note: It marks the absolute beginning, not just a phase. Think of the "Genesis" of an idea, a project, or even a universe. It's the foundational spark.

content.meaning_en: The study of heredity and the variation of inherited characteristics.
usage_sentences: She is a leading researcher in the field of human genetics.
Advances in genetics have led to new treatments for many diseases.
content.note: Genetics unravels the blueprint of life, explaining why we inherit traits and how species evolve. It's the science behind family resemblances and biological diversity.
content.origin: From 'gene', which comes from Greek 'genos' (race, kind).

content.meaning_en: Exceptional intellectual or creative power or other natural ability.
usage_sentences: Leonardo da Vinci was a true genius, excelling in both art and science.
She has a genius for solving complex mathematical problems.
content.note: More than intelligence, genius implies an innate, extraordinary capacity for innovation or profound understanding. It's often marked by groundbreaking insights that redefine fields.
content.origin: From Latin 'genius', originally 'attendant spirit present from one's birth'.

content.meaning_en: The deliberate killing of a large group of people, especially those of a particular ethnic group or nation.
usage_sentences: The international community has a duty to prevent genocide.
He was put on trial for committing acts of genocide.
content.note: This isn't just mass murder; it's the intentional extermination of a specific group, aiming to eradicate their existence. A horrifying act against humanity itself.

content.meaning_en: Truly what something is said to be; authentic.
usage_sentences: This is a genuine leather handbag, not a cheap imitation.
He showed genuine remorse for his actions.
content.note: Genuine implies authenticity, free from pretense or fakery. It describes something real, whether an emotion, an artifact, or a person's character, standing true to itself.

content.meaning_en: The study of the physical features of the earth and its atmosphere, and of human activity as it affects and is affected by these.
usage_sentences: In geography class, we learned about the world's major rivers and mountains.
The geography of the region, with its mountains and deserts, makes travel difficult.
content.note: Geography connects physical landscapes with human societies, revealing how mountains, rivers, and climate shape cultures, economies, and politics. It’s the study of "where" and "why there."

content.meaning_en: The science that deals with the earth's physical structure and substance, its history, and the processes which act on it.
usage_sentences: He is studying geology at the university to become a geoscientist.
The geology of the area is rich in mineral deposits.
content.note: Geology delves into Earth's deep past and dynamic present, from shifting continents to erupting volcanoes. It reveals our planet's slow, powerful evolution and the forces shaping its surface.

content.meaning_en: Plural of geologist (a scientist who studies geology).
usage_sentences: Geologists were sent to study the site after the earthquake.
The team of geologists discovered a large deposit of iron ore.
content.note: These scientists decipher Earth's autobiography, reading rocks like ancient texts. They uncover mineral wealth, predict natural disasters, and reconstruct our planet's billions of years of transformation.

content.meaning_en: The scientific study of old age, the process of aging, and the particular problems of old people.
usage_sentences: Research in gerontology aims to improve the quality of life for the elderly.
She is a professor of gerontology at the medical university.
content.note: Gerontology explores the multifaceted journey of aging, from biological changes to social impacts. It seeks to understand and improve quality of life for an ever-growing older population.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A movement of part of the body, especially a hand or the head, to express an idea or meaning. (Verb) - Move one's hand or head to express an idea or feeling.
usage_sentences: He made a welcoming gesture with his hands.
In many cultures, a nod is a common gesture of agreement.
content.note: Gestures bridge spoken language, conveying nuance, emotion, or emphasis non-verbally. A simple nod or wave can speak volumes, often unconsciously, revealing true intent.
content.origin: From medieval Latin 'gestura', from 'gerere' (to bear, carry).

content.meaning_en: A slowly moving mass or river of ice formed by the accumulation and compaction of snow on mountains or near the poles.
usage_sentences: Climate change is causing glaciers around the world to melt at an alarming rate.
The massive glacier carved out the valley thousands of years ago.
content.note: Glaciers are colossal, ancient rivers of ice, sculptors of landscapes that carve valleys and transport rock. They are vital climate indicators, reflecting changes in Earth's temperature.

content.meaning_en: An alphabetical list of terms or words found in or relating to a specific subject, text, or dialect, with explanations.
usage_sentences: If you don't understand a technical term in this book, look it up in the glossary.
The textbook includes a glossary of important scientific terms.
content.note: A glossary serves as a mini-dictionary tailored to a specific work, demystifying specialized terminology. It helps readers navigate complex subjects by providing quick, contextual definitions.
content.origin: From late Latin 'glossarium', from Greek 'glōssa' (tongue, language).

content.meaning_en: An excessively greedy eater.
usage_sentences: He ate the entire cake by himself; he's such a glutton!
He is a glutton for punishment, always taking on the most difficult tasks.
content.note: A glutton isn't just someone who enjoys food, but one driven by insatiable, often self-destructive, desire for excessive consumption. It highlights a lack of restraint.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - transplant of living tissue. (Verb) - Insert or fix (a shoot or twig) as a graft.
usage_sentences: The doctor performed a skin graft to help the burn victim heal.
The politician was accused of accepting a graft in exchange for favors.
content.note: Grafting involves fusing living tissues—a branch onto a tree, or skin onto a body—to heal or create new growth. It's a powerful technique for biological integration.
content.origin: From Old French 'grafe', from Greek 'graphein' (to write), via the sense of a stylus-shaped shoot.

content.meaning_en: The process of graft (insert or fix (a shoot or twig) as a graft).
usage_sentences: Grafting is a common horticultural technique to join two plants together.
The surgeon was an expert in bone grafting procedures.
content.note: Grafting merges different plants, combining strengths like root vigor with fruit quality. In medicine, it's vital for tissue repair and organ transplantation, integrating new life.

content.meaning_en: A storehouse for grain or animal feed.
usage_sentences: The farmer stored the freshly harvested wheat in the granary.
Ancient Rome had large public granaries to ensure a stable food supply.
content.note: A granary is more than a storage unit; it's a vital food security infrastructure. Historically, civilizations relied on granaries to sustain populations through lean seasons.

content.meaning_en: The study of handwriting and especially its use in inferring character and aptitudes.
usage_sentences: Some companies use graphology to analyze job applicants' personalities.
She hired a graphology expert to verify the signature on the document.
content.note: Graphology claims to reveal personality traits, moods, and even health from handwriting. While its scientific validity is debated, it offers an intriguing lens into human expression.

content.meaning_en: A glass building in which plants are grown that need protection from cold weather.
usage_sentences: They grow tomatoes and exotic flowers in their greenhouse all winter.
A greenhouse works by trapping the sun's heat.
content.note: A greenhouse traps solar energy, creating a warm, controlled microclimate. It allows cultivation of delicate plants, extends growing seasons, and showcases biological diversity irrespective of external conditions.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Reduce (something) to small particles or powder by crushing it. (Noun) - Hard, laborious work.
usage_sentences: You need to grind the coffee beans to make fresh coffee.
The daily grind of working two jobs was exhausting.
content.note: "Grind" captures both physical reduction and relentless effort. The commonality is repetitive, intensive action, whether transforming coffee beans or pushing through a challenging workday.
content.origin: From Old English 'grindan', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A room or building equipped for gymnastics, games, and other physical exercise.
usage_sentences: He goes to the gym every morning before work.
The school's new gymnasium has a swimming pool and a basketball court.
content.note: A gym is a space dedicated to physical development and well-being. From ancient Greek training grounds to modern fitness centers, it embodies the pursuit of bodily strength and health.
content.origin: From Greek 'gumnasion', from 'gumnos' (naked), as athletes trained unclothed.

content.meaning_en: A physician specializing in gynecology, the branch of medicine dealing with disorders of the female reproductive system.
usage_sentences: It is recommended to have a regular check-up with a gynecologist.
She consulted a gynecologist about her health concerns.
content.note: Gynecologists play a crucial role in women's health, providing care from adolescence through menopause. Their expertise addresses unique reproductive system needs, vital for overall well-being.
content.origin: From 'gynecology', which is from Greek 'gunē' (woman) and '-logia' (study).

content.meaning_en: The branch of medicine concerned with the study of the cause, prognosis, treatment, and prevention of diseases related to blood.
usage_sentences: The patient was referred to the haematology department for blood tests.
Haematology deals with diseases like anemia and leukemia.
content.note: Haematology explores the intricate world of blood, diagnosing and treating disorders like anemia or leukemia. Blood, though fluid, is a complex tissue critical for oxygen transport and immunity.

content.meaning_en: An experience involving the apparent perception of something not present.
usage_sentences: The high fever caused the patient to have vivid hallucinations.
Certain drugs can induce powerful hallucinations.
content.note: Hallucinations are sensory experiences without external stimuli, blurring the line between perception and reality. They can manifest across any sense, from seeing visions to hearing voices, originating internally.
content.origin: From Latin 'hallucinatio(n-)', from 'hallucinari' (to wander in mind).

content.meaning_en: A drug that causes hallucinations.
usage_sentences: LSD is a well-known synthetic hallucinogen.
The use of hallucinogens can have long-lasting psychological effects.
content.note: Hallucinogens profoundly alter perception, mood, and thought, often leading to vivid sensory experiences and altered states of consciousness. They unlock pathways to non-ordinary reality, for better or worse.

content.meaning_en: Creative work with one's hands; design and production of useful and decorative objects by hand.
usage_sentences: The local market is famous for its beautiful handicrafts.
She sells her handmade jewelry and other handicrafts online.
content.note: Handicraft embodies human creativity and skill, producing unique items that bear the artisan's touch. It preserves traditional methods, offers personalized aesthetics, and often connects us to cultural heritage.

content.meaning_en: Subject to aggressive pressure or intimidation.
usage_sentences: It is against the law to harass someone in the workplace.
She reported her neighbor to the police for constantly harassing her.
content.note: Harassment involves persistent, unwelcome actions that create a hostile environment. It's about power imbalance and eroding a person's peace, dignity, or sense of security through intimidation.
content.origin: From Old French 'harer', meaning 'to set a dog on'.

content.meaning_en: Cruel or severe; unkind.
usage_sentences: The dictator was known for his harsh treatment of political opponents.
Living conditions in the refugee camp were very harsh.
content.note: Harsh describes severity, whether in criticism, conditions, or judgment. It implies a lack of gentleness or compassion, often leaving a stinging impact on those experiencing it.
content.origin: Of Middle German origin, related to 'hairy'.

content.meaning_en: In a hearty manner; sincerely; enthusiastically.
usage_sentences: They all laughed heartily at his joke.
After the long hike, they ate heartily.
content.note: "Heartily" conveys genuine enthusiasm and sincerity, often implying robust health or spirited engagement. To laugh heartily is to laugh fully, without reservation, from the depths of one's being.
content.origin: From the word 'hearty', derived from Old English 'heorte' (heart).

content.meaning_en: Extremely distressing; agonizing.
usage_sentences: The movie told the heart-wrenching story of a family torn apart by war.
It was a heart-wrenching decision to put their old dog to sleep.
content.note: This powerful term describes an emotional pain so profound it feels physically tearing. It's used for deeply sorrowful or tragic events that evoke intense empathy and suffering.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Pay attention to; take notice of. (Noun) - Careful attention.
usage_sentences: You should heed the warnings about the approaching storm.
He failed to heed his lawyer's advice and ended up in trouble.
content.note: To heed is to give careful attention and follow advice, signifying respect for wisdom or warnings. Ignoring heed can lead to regrettable consequences, underscoring its importance.
content.origin: From Old English 'hēdan', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A person legally entitled to the property or rank of another on that person's death.
usage_sentences: As the eldest son, he is the heir to the family fortune.
The prince is the heir to the throne.
content.note: An heir inherits not just property, but often a legacy, responsibility, or even a burden. It signifies a direct link to the past, carrying forward influence into the future.

content.meaning_en: A plane figure with seven straight sides and seven angles.
usage_sentences: The teacher asked the students to identify the heptagon among the shapes.
A heptagon has seven vertices and seven angles.
content.note: Heptagons are fascinating for their sevenfold symmetry, distinct from more common polygons. They appear in architecture and nature, though less frequently than hexagons or octagons, making them unique.

content.meaning_en: An animal that feeds on plants.
usage_sentences: Cows, elephants, and deer are examples of herbivores.
The large dinosaur was a herbivore, despite its size.
content.note: Herbivores are foundational to ecosystems, converting plant energy into a usable form for other animals. Their digestive systems are uniquely adapted to break down fibrous plant material efficiently.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A large group of animals, especially hoofed mammals, that live together or are kept together as livestock. (Verb) - Move in a herd.
usage_sentences: A herd of cattle was grazing peacefully in the pasture.
The tour guide spotted a large herd of elephants near the waterhole.
content.note: "Herd" describes both a collective animal group and the act of guiding them. The instinct to herd offers protection in numbers, but also susceptibility to collective panic or control.
content.origin: From Old English 'heord', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A person living in solitude as a religious discipline.
usage_sentences: The hermit lived a simple life in a remote cabin in the woods.
He chose to become a hermit to escape the pressures of modern society.
content.note: A hermit seeks spiritual growth through isolation, withdrawing from societal distractions. This path emphasizes self-reliance, contemplation, and a deeper connection to inner truths, away from worldly clamor.

content.meaning_en: Pause before saying or doing something, especially through uncertainty or reluctance.
usage_sentences: Don't hesitate to ask for help if you need it.
She hesitated for a moment before answering the difficult question.
content.note: Hesitation is a momentary suspension of action, often revealing inner conflict or caution. It can signify prudence, fear, or simply a need for more time to process a decision.
content.origin: From Latin 'haesitare', from 'haerere' (to stick, hold fast).

content.meaning_en: Diverse in character or content.
usage_sentences: New York City has a very heterogeneous population.
The student body at the university is culturally heterogeneous.
content.note: Heterogeneous signifies a mixture of distinct, often contrasting elements. Think of a diverse classroom or a complex stew; its strength lies in the rich variety of its components, not uniformity.

content.meaning_en: A plane figure with six straight sides and six angles.
usage_sentences: A honeycomb is made up of many small hexagonal cells.
A standard nut or bolt head is often in the shape of a hexagon.
content.note: Hexagons are remarkably efficient, appearing in beehives and snowflakes due to their optimal packing density. This six-sided structure maximizes space and strength in natural and engineered designs.

content.meaning_en: (Of an animal) spend the winter in a dormant state.
usage_sentences: Bears find a den to hibernate in during the cold winter months.
Some species of frogs and turtles also hibernate.
content.note: Hibernation is nature's ingenious survival strategy, a deep sleep minimizing metabolic activity to conserve energy during harsh winters. It's a physiological marvel, adapting life to environmental extremes.

content.meaning_en: The condition or period of an animal or plant hibernating.
usage_sentences: The bear emerged from its long winter hibernation.
Hibernation allows animals to conserve energy when food is scarce.
content.note: Hibernation is a state of profound physiological change, where animals drastically lower their body temperature, heart rate, and metabolism. It allows survival when food is scarce, an ultimate energy-saving mode.

content.meaning_en: Unlawfully seize (an aircraft, vehicle, or ship) in transit and force it to go to a different destination or use it for one's own purposes.
usage_sentences: The terrorists attempted to hijack the airplane.
His truck was hijacked and the cargo was stolen.
content.note: Hijacking involves unauthorized, forceful takeover, turning a journey of transit into a tool for illicit intent. It disrupts order, asserts coercive control, and often instills terror.
content.origin: From US slang, of uncertain origin, possibly from 'highwayman' + 'jacker'.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Make a sharp sibilant sound as of the letter s. (Noun) - A sibilant sound.
usage_sentences: The snake reared its head and began to hiss.
The angry cat arched its back and let out a loud hiss.
content.note: A hiss often signals warning, aggression, or contempt, like a snake's threat. It's a primal, breathy sound, universally understood as a sign of discomfort or disapproval.

content.meaning_en: A beehive, especially one of made by humans.
usage_sentences: The beekeeper collected honey from the hive.
The office was a hive of activity before the deadline.
content.note: A hive is more than a home; it's a complex, self-organizing superorganism. Each bee plays a role, contributing to the colony's survival and the production of honey and wax.

content.meaning_en: The killing of one human being by another.
usage_sentences: The police are investigating the death as a possible homicide.
He was charged with vehicular homicide after the drunk-driving accident.
content.note: Homicide is the ultimate act against another life, covering a spectrum from accidental to premeditated. It signifies the tragic cessation of existence at the hands of another person.

content.meaning_en: Of the same kind; alike.
usage_sentences: The population of the small village was remarkably homogeneous.
Stir the mixture until it becomes a homogeneous liquid.
content.note: Homogeneous describes uniformity, where all parts are identical or very similar. While offering consistency, it can lack the richness or resilience found in diverse, heterogeneous systems.

content.meaning_en: Each of two or more words having the same spelling or pronunciation but different meanings and origins.
usage_sentences: The words 'bat' (animal) and 'bat' (sports equipment) are homonyms.
Understanding homonyms is an important part of learning English.
content.note: Homonyms are linguistic tricksters, like "bank" (river vs. financial). They highlight the fluidity of language, where identical sounds or spellings carry distinct, unrelated meanings, often causing confusion.

content.meaning_en: A payment given for professional services that are rendered nominally without charge.
usage_sentences: The guest lecturer received a small honorarium for his talk.
The organization paid him an honorarium to cover his travel expenses.
content.note: An honorarium is a gesture of appreciation for services performed pro bono, recognizing time and expertise without a formal fee. It acknowledges value beyond mere monetary transaction, upholding dignity.

content.meaning_en: (Of an office or position) held or given as an honor, without payment for services.
usage_sentences: The university awarded him an honorary doctorate degree.
She serves as the honorary chairperson of the charity.
content.note: An honorary title confers prestige and recognition without salary or full responsibilities. It celebrates significant contributions or status, acknowledging distinction rather than demanding labor.

content.meaning_en: Worthy of honor; respected.
usage_sentences: He is an honourable man who always keeps his promises.
It was the honourable thing to do, even though it was difficult.
content.note: To be honourable is to possess integrity, adhering to high moral principles. It signifies trustworthiness, ethical conduct, and commands respect, forming the bedrock of personal and public reputation.
content.origin: From Old French 'honorable', from Latin 'honorabilis' (worthy of honor).

content.meaning_en: The line at which the earth's surface and the sky appear to meet.
usage_sentences: We watched the beautiful sunset as the sun sank below the horizon.
New scientific discoveries are always on the horizon.
content.note: The horizon is both a physical boundary and a symbolic limit. It represents the edge of our perception, an attainable goal, or the infinite unknown stretching beyond our sight.

content.meaning_en: Friendly and welcoming to strangers or guests.
usage_sentences: The local people were very hospitable and invited us into their homes for dinner.
The hotel is known for its hospitable atmosphere and excellent service.
content.note: A truly hospitable person offers warmth and generosity, making guests feel like family. It's more than just politeness; it's genuine openness.

content.meaning_en: The friendly and generous reception and entertainment of guests, visitors, or strangers.
usage_sentences: They thanked their hosts for their warm hospitality during their stay.
The tourism industry relies on providing excellent hospitality.
content.note: It's the art of making guests feel welcomed and comfortable. Excellent hospitality transforms a simple stay into a memorable experience, reflecting true generosity of spirit.

content.meaning_en: A woman who receives or entertains guests.
usage_sentences: The hostess greeted each guest at the door with a warm smile.
She was a wonderful hostess, making sure everyone had enough to eat and drink.
content.note: Beyond just receiving guests, a hostess often orchestrates the social flow and comfort of an event. She ensures everyone feels at ease, embodying the spirit of welcome.
content.origin: From Old French 'hostesse', from Latin 'hospes' (guest, host).

content.meaning_en: The organic component of soil, formed by the decomposition of leaves and other plant material by soil microorganisms.
usage_sentences: Rich in humus, this soil is perfect for growing vegetables.
Adding compost to the garden increases the humus content of the soil.
content.note: This dark, rich soil component is vital for plant growth. It retains water and nutrients, transforming dead organic matter into life-sustaining energy for ecosystems.

content.meaning_en: A storm with a violent wind, in particular a tropical cyclone in the Caribbean.
usage_sentences: The coastal city was devastated by the powerful hurricane.
Forecasters warned residents to evacuate before the hurricane made landfall.
content.note: This powerful tropical cyclone forms over warm ocean waters, bringing destructive winds and torrential rain. Its immense energy profoundly reshapes coastlines and communities in its path.
content.origin: From Spanish 'huracán', from a Taino (Caribbean) word.

content.meaning_en: Done in a hurry; rushed.
usage_sentences: She ate a hurried breakfast before running out the door.
The decision was a hurried one, and they later regretted it.
content.note: Implies a lack of carefulness due to speed. A hurried decision might overlook crucial details, leading to less optimal outcomes than a thoughtfully executed one.
content.origin: From the verb 'hurry', of uncertain origin.

content.meaning_en: In a hurried manner; rapidly; quickly.
usage_sentences: He hurriedly packed his bags and left the hotel.
The note was written hurriedly and was difficult to read.
content.note: This adverb describes actions executed with great speed, often at the expense of precision or consideration. Working hurriedly can indicate urgency but risks overlooked details or errors.

content.meaning_en: Extreme or irrational fear of water, especially as a symptom of rabies in humans.
usage_sentences: A key symptom of advanced rabies is hydrophobia, making it difficult for the patient to swallow.
His hydrophobia was so severe that he couldn't even take a shower.
content.note: While broadly a fear of water, it's chillingly iconic as a symptom of advanced rabies. The inability to swallow water makes even the thought of it terrifying for sufferers.

content.meaning_en: The practice of claiming to have moral standards or beliefs to which one's own behavior does not conform; pretense.
usage_sentences: It's sheer hypocrisy for him to talk about saving money when he spends so much.
She accused the politician of hypocrisy for breaking his campaign promises.
content.note: The stark disconnect between professed values and actual behavior defines hypocrisy. It undermines trust and reveals a fundamental insincerity, often rooted in self-deception or a desire for moral appearance.
content.origin: From Greek 'hupokrisis', meaning 'acting of a theatrical part'.

content.meaning_en: A person who indulges in hypocrisy.
usage_sentences: He's a hypocrite; he tells us to be eco-friendly but drives a gas-guzzling car.
Don't be a hypocrite; practice what you preach.
content.note: This individual preaches virtues they don't practice, creating a facade of morality. A hypocrite's words ring hollow, eroding credibility and revealing a deceptive nature.

content.meaning_en: A supposition or proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for further investigation.
usage_sentences: The scientist formulated a hypothesis to explain the strange results.
Further experiments are needed to test this hypothesis.
content.note: A scientific hypothesis is a testable, educated guess, serving as a foundation for experiments. It's not yet a theory but a crucial first step in understanding phenomena through inquiry.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Perfectly suitable; most appropriate. (Noun) - A standard of perfection; a principle to be aimed at.
usage_sentences: This sunny weather is ideal for a picnic in the park.
She strives to live up to her high moral ideals.
content.note: As an adjective, it means perfect; as a noun, it's a goal or standard of excellence. Striving for an ideal often drives progress, even if absolute perfection is elusive.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Not active or in use. (Verb) - Spend time doing nothing; be lazy.
usage_sentences: The old factory has been lying idle for years.
He spent the afternoon just idling around the house.
content.note: To be idle means inactive or lazy, while to idle is to waste time. An idle mind can be fertile ground for creativity or, conversely, unproductive stagnation.

content.meaning_en: An image or representation of a god used as an object of worship.
usage_sentences: The ancient temple contained a large golden idol.
He is a pop idol with millions of teenage fans.
content.note: An idol is an object of worship or intense admiration. In modern use, it refers to anyone or anything revered, often to an excessive, almost religious degree, in pop culture.

content.meaning_en: A dome-shaped house built of blocks of solid snow, traditionally used by Eskimos.
usage_sentences: The hunter built a temporary igloo for shelter during the blizzard.
Inside the igloo, it was surprisingly warm compared to the outside.
content.note: These ingenious snow shelters are incredibly effective insulators, trapping body heat and keeping inhabitants surprisingly warm. Their dome shape provides structural strength against harsh winds.

content.meaning_en: Refuse to take notice of or acknowledge; disregard intentionally.
usage_sentences: He chose to ignore the warning signs and continued on his path.
If you ignore the problem, it will only get worse.
content.note: To ignore is a deliberate act of non-acknowledgment, often chosen to avoid engagement or to convey indifference. It can be a powerful tool, for good or ill.
content.origin: From Latin 'ignorare', meaning 'not to know, to disregard'.

content.meaning_en: Poor physical or mental condition; sickness.
usage_sentences: He had to retire early due to persistent ill health.
A poor diet and lack of exercise can lead to ill health.
content.note: This term encompasses a state of diminished well-being, both physically and mentally. It signifies a departure from a healthy condition, impacting daily life and requiring care.

content.meaning_en: Not clear enough to be read.
usage_sentences: The doctor's handwriting was completely illegible.
The old document was faded and largely illegible.
content.note: When handwriting is illegible, its meaning remains obscured, defeating the purpose of written communication. It demands deciphering or remains forever unread, a silent frustration.

content.meaning_en: Forbidden by law, rules, or custom.
usage_sentences: He was arrested for selling illicit drugs.
The company was investigated for illicit financial activities.
content.note: Illicit refers to something unlawful or forbidden, carrying a connotation of impropriety and secrecy. An illicit act operates outside societal boundaries, often with consequences.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Unable to read or write. (Noun) - A person who is unable to read or write.
usage_sentences: The organization works to help illiterate adults learn to read.
In the 19th century, a large portion of the population was illiterate.
content.note: An illiterate person lacks fundamental literacy skills, significantly hindering their ability to navigate modern society. It's a barrier to education, information, and full participation.

content.meaning_en: Light up.
usage_sentences: The fireworks will illuminate the night sky.
The professor's lecture helped to illuminate a difficult topic.
content.note: Beyond literally lighting a space, to illuminate also means to clarify or enlighten. A brilliant idea can illuminate a complex problem, making understanding dawn on the mind.

content.meaning_en: A picture illustrating a book, newspaper, etc.
usage_sentences: The children's book was filled with colorful illustrations.
A clear illustration can help explain a complex idea.
content.note: An illustration provides visual context or explanation, enhancing understanding of accompanying text. It transforms abstract ideas into concrete images, making complex information more accessible and engaging.
content.origin: From Latin 'illustrare', meaning 'to light up, explain'.

content.meaning_en: Existing only in the imagination; not real.
usage_sentences: As a child, she had an imaginary friend named Leo.
Dragons and unicorns are imaginary creatures.
content.note: Existing solely in the mind, imaginary things are products of creative thought, not reality. They allow us to explore possibilities, build fictional worlds, and solve problems conceptually.

content.meaning_en: Capable of being imitated.
usage_sentences: His simple yet effective technique is highly imitable.
She has a unique style that is not easily imitable.
content.note: If something is imitable, it can be copied or modeled. This quality is crucial in learning and skill development, allowing individuals to reproduce successful actions or artistic styles.

content.meaning_en: Take or follow as a model.
usage_sentences: Parrots are known for their ability to imitate human speech.
He tried to imitate his hero's style of painting.
content.note: To imitate is to reproduce an action, sound, or behavior, often for learning or amusement. It's a fundamental aspect of human development, from childhood mimicry to artistic homage.

content.meaning_en: A thing intended to simulate or copy something else.
usage_sentences: She wore imitation pearls that looked just like the real thing.
The painting was a clever imitation of a famous masterpiece.
content.note: An imitation is a copy or replica, designed to resemble an original. While some imitations are high-quality tributes, others are cheap counterfeits, lacking the original's value.

content.meaning_en: Not able to be moved; motionless.
usage_sentences: He sat immobile for hours, staring out the window.
A broken engine left the car immobile on the side of the road.
content.note: Immobile signifies a state of being utterly still, whether by design, constraint, or injury. It implies an inability to move, rendering something fixed or temporarily paralyzed.

content.meaning_en: A person who comes to live permanently in a foreign country.
usage_sentences: My grandparents were immigrants from Italy who came to America for a better life.
The city has a large and diverse immigrant population.
content.note: An immigrant makes the brave decision to settle permanently in a new country, seeking opportunity or refuge. Their journey enriches cultures and economies, bringing diverse perspectives and skills.

content.meaning_en: Not conforming to accepted standards of morality; wicked.
usage_sentences: Lying and cheating are considered immoral behaviors.
The book was banned for its supposedly immoral content.
content.note: Immoral actions actively violate accepted moral principles, demonstrating a conscious disregard for what is considered right. It implies a sense of wrongdoing, distinct from merely being amoral.

content.meaning_en: Resistant to a particular infection or toxin owing to the presence of specific antibodies or sensitized white blood cells.
usage_sentences: After getting the vaccine, you will be immune to the disease.
No one is immune to criticism.
content.note: To be immune is to possess robust resistance against disease or harm. Beyond biology, one can be immune to persuasion, implying a steadfast refusal to be affected by external influence.
content.origin: From Latin 'immunis', meaning 'exempt from public service'.

content.meaning_en: The ability of an organism to resist a particular infection or toxin by the action of specific antibodies or sensitized white blood cells.
usage_sentences: Vaccination helps to build up immunity against serious diseases.
The diplomat claimed diplomatic immunity to avoid being arrested.
content.note: This protective state, whether biological or legal, shields an individual from harm or prosecution. It represents a specialized defense mechanism, providing resistance against specific threats or liabilities.

content.meaning_en: A charge of misconduct made against the holder of a public office.
usage_sentences: The president faced impeachment for his alleged crimes.
The impeachment process is a serious constitutional matter.
content.note: Impeachment is the formal accusation of misconduct against a public official. It's a critical constitutional mechanism for accountability, not removal itself, but the initiation of a trial process.

content.meaning_en: Make or become better.
usage_sentences: She took extra classes to improve her grades.
The weather is expected to improve tomorrow.
content.note: To improve is to enhance quality, performance, or condition. This continuous process reflects growth and development, aiming for a higher standard, whether personally or systemically.
content.origin: From Anglo-Norman French 'emprower', meaning 'to turn to profit'.

content.meaning_en: Unable to be reached.
usage_sentences: The remote mountain village is inaccessible during the winter.
The ancient ruins are located in a very inaccessible part of the jungle.
content.note: Something inaccessible cannot be reached, whether physically, intellectually, or emotionally. It presents a barrier, making connection or understanding impossible until the obstruction is overcome.

content.meaning_en: Unable to express oneself clearly or fluently.
usage_sentences: He was so nervous during the interview that he became completely inarticulate.
She made a few inarticulate sounds of protest.
content.note: An inarticulate person struggles to convey thoughts clearly, often due to strong emotion or a lack of vocabulary. Their message becomes garbled, making understanding a challenge for others.

content.meaning_en: Unable to be heard.
usage_sentences: His whisper was almost inaudible in the noisy room.
The sound was at a frequency that is inaudible to the human ear.
content.note: If a sound is inaudible, it's either too faint, too high/low in frequency, or completely silent to the human ear. Its existence remains undetected, a whisper lost in the air.

content.meaning_en: A thing that motivates or encourages one to do something.
usage_sentences: The company offered a financial incentive for employees who met their sales targets.
Tax incentives are used to encourage investment in the region.
content.note: An incentive acts as a powerful motivator, encouraging specific actions or behaviors. It's often a reward or benefit, strategically designed to drive productivity, compliance, or innovation.
content.origin: From late Latin 'incentivum', meaning 'something that sets the tune'.

content.meaning_en: Not able to be understood; not intelligible.
usage_sentences: The technical manual was completely incomprehensible to me.
He was speaking so fast that his words were incomprehensible.
content.note: Something incomprehensible defies understanding, whether due to complexity, illogic, or sheer unfamiliarity. It leaves one baffled, unable to grasp its meaning or implications.

content.meaning_en: Not able to be denied or disputed.
usage_sentences: The DNA evidence provided incontrovertible proof of his guilt.
The facts of the case are incontrovertible.
content.note: Incontrovertible evidence or facts are beyond any reasonable doubt or challenge. They stand as undeniable truths, forming an irrefutable basis for argument or conclusion.
content.origin: From 'in-' (not) and 'controvertible', from Latin 'contra' (against) and 'vertere' (to turn).

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - Trouble or difficulty caused to one's personal circumstances. (Verb) - Cause trouble or difficulty to (someone).
usage_sentences: We apologize for any inconvenience caused by the delay.
I hope my late arrival did not inconvenience you.
content.note: As a noun, it's a minor annoyance; as a verb, it means causing trouble. An inconvenience disrupts one's plans or comfort, usually mildly, but can accumulate to frustrate greatly.
content.origin: From late Latin 'inconvenientia', from 'in-' (not) and 'conveniens' (agreeing, suitable).

content.meaning_en: Difficult or impossible to believe.
usage_sentences: He told an incredible story about his adventure in the jungle.
The view from the top of the mountain was absolutely incredible.
content.note: While literally meaning unbelievable, "incredible" often conveys astonishment or impressiveness, implying something so extraordinary it seems hard to credit. An incredible feat leaves us awestruck.

content.meaning_en: Owing money to someone.
usage_sentences: The company is heavily indebted to the banks.
I am deeply indebted to you for all your help.
content.note: Beyond financial obligations, being indebted can mean owing deep gratitude for a favor or kindness. This emotional debt inspires a desire to reciprocate, forging a bond of reciprocity.
content.origin: From Old French 'endeté', based on Latin 'debitum' (debt).

content.meaning_en: Beyond description; that cannot be described.
usage_sentences: The beauty of the sunset was indescribable.
He felt a sense of joy that was simply indescribable.
content.note: When something is indescribable, its essence is too profound, complex, or overwhelming for words to capture fully. It transcends linguistic limitations, experienced more deeply than articulated.

content.meaning_en: Originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native.
usage_sentences: The Maori are the indigenous people of New Zealand.
This type of plant is indigenous to the Amazon rainforest.
content.note: Indigenous refers to species or peoples originating naturally in a particular region. Their deep connection to the land reflects a long history, adapting uniquely to their native environment and culture.
content.origin: From late Latin 'indigenus', from 'indi-' (within) and 'gignere' (to beget).

content.meaning_en: Diligent and hard-working.
usage_sentences: She is an industrious student who always completes her assignments on time.
The industrious workers finished the project ahead of schedule.
content.note: An industrious person demonstrates consistent diligence and hard work, pursuing tasks with persistent effort. Their dedication often leads to significant achievements and productivity, embodying a strong work ethic.

content.meaning_en: Not fit or suitable for eating.
usage_sentences: Some types of wild berries are inedible and can be poisonous.
The meal was so badly cooked that it was almost inedible.
content.note: Something inedible isn't necessarily poisonous; it simply isn't palatable or suitable for consumption. It might be too tough, tasteless, or otherwise unsuitable, despite being harmless.

content.meaning_en: Not eligible to do or to qualify for something.
usage_sentences: You are ineligible for the scholarship because you missed the application deadline.
Players who have tested positive for drugs are ineligible to compete.
content.note: To be ineligible means failing to meet the required criteria or qualifications for something. This status prevents participation or access, often due to specific rules or conditions.

content.meaning_en: Lacking the ability or strength to move.
usage_sentences: He lay inert in the hospital bed after the accident.
Noble gases like helium and neon are chemically inert.
content.note: Inert describes a state of complete inactivity or resistance to change. In chemistry, it signifies unreactive substances, while broadly, it refers to something motionless, lifeless, or unresponsive.

content.meaning_en: Impossible to extinguish.
usage_sentences: The chemical fire was nearly inextinguishable.
She had an inextinguishable passion for learning.
content.note: Beyond literal flames, "inextinguishable" describes a spirit or passion impossible to suppress. It signifies enduring strength, resilience, and an unyielding light that persists despite adversity.

content.meaning_en: Incapable of making mistakes or being wrong.
usage_sentences: No human being is infallible; everyone makes mistakes.
He had an infallible memory and could recall every detail.
content.note: To be infallible is to possess absolute certainty, never erring. While often applied to divine authority, in human terms, it describes unshakeable reliability, though rarely achieved perfectly.
content.origin: From ecclesiastical Latin 'infallibilis', from 'in-' (not) and 'fallibilis' (liable to err).

content.meaning_en: The crime of killing a child within a year of birth.
usage_sentences: The community was shocked by the tragic case of infanticide.
Laws against infanticide are meant to protect the most vulnerable.
content.note: Infanticide specifically refers to the tragic act of killing a child within their first year of life, distinguishing it from other forms of child homicide by this critical age limit.

content.meaning_en: Limitless or endless in space, extent, or size; impossible to measure or calculate.
usage_sentences: The universe is vast and possibly infinite.
The teacher seemed to have an infinite amount of patience.
content.note: Infinite describes a boundless concept, not merely 'very large,' extending without limits in space, extent, or size, making it impossible to fully grasp or quantify.

content.meaning_en: Easily set on fire.
usage_sentences: Gasoline and other inflammable liquids should be stored safely.
Warning signs indicated that the material was highly inflammable.
content.note: Be careful! "Inflammable" means the exact same thing as "flammable": easily set on fire. The prefix 'in-' here intensifies, rather than negates.

content.meaning_en: Not guilty of a crime or offense.
usage_sentences: The court found the defendant innocent of all charges.
He had an innocent look on his face, but I knew he was lying.
content.note: Beyond legal innocence, it implies a lack of experience or corruption, reflecting purity or naivety in character, often seen in children.

content.meaning_en: (Of a product, idea, etc.) featuring new methods; advanced and original.
usage_sentences: The company is known for its innovative approach to product design.
She came up with an innovative solution to the problem.
content.note: Innovative ideas or products aren't just new; they introduce advanced, original methods that often solve problems more effectively or create new possibilities.
content.origin: From late Latin 'innovatus', from the verb 'innovare' (to renew).

content.meaning_en: Write or carve (words or symbols) on something, especially as a formal or permanent record.
usage_sentences: They decided to inscribe the date of their anniversary on their wedding rings.
His name was inscribed on the war memorial.
content.note: To inscribe is to mark something permanently, often with significant words or symbols, ensuring its record endures through time, like on a monument.

content.meaning_en: Words inscribed, as on a monument or in a book.
usage_sentences: The archaeologist carefully studied the ancient inscription on the stone tablet.
The inscription on the trophy read 'World Champion'.
content.note: An inscription provides a lasting message, often a dedication or historical record, etched onto a durable surface, offering silent testimony across generations.

content.meaning_en: Impossible to solve.
usage_sentences: Oil is insoluble in water.
The mystery of the missing plane seemed to be an insoluble puzzle.
content.note: "Insoluble" primarily refers to a substance incapable of dissolving in a solvent, like oil in water. It also describes a problem that cannot be solved.

content.meaning_en: Impossible to solve.
usage_sentences: The detective faced a seemingly insolvable case.
For a long time, the mathematical problem was considered insolvable.
content.note: "Insolvable" refers exclusively to a problem that cannot be resolved or answered. Unlike "insoluble," it does not apply to substances unable to dissolve.

content.meaning_en: Protected by interposing material that prevents the loss of heat or intrusion of sound.
usage_sentences: A well-insulated house stays warm in the winter and cool in the summer.
The electrical wires are insulated with a plastic coating.
content.note: Insulated means protected from heat, sound, or electricity. Metaphorically, one can be insulated from difficult realities, suggesting a state of detachment or privilege.

content.meaning_en: Combine (one thing) with another so that they become a whole.
usage_sentences: The new software will integrate with our existing systems.
The school's goal is to integrate students of all backgrounds.
content.note: To integrate is more than just combining; it's about forming a cohesive, functional whole where all parts work harmoniously together, often creating synergy.

content.meaning_en: The quality of being honest and having strong moral principles; moral uprightness.
usage_sentences: He is a man of great integrity who can be trusted completely.
Maintaining the structural integrity of the old bridge is a top priority.
content.note: Integrity encompasses both moral uprightness and the state of being whole and undivided. A person of integrity is honest; a structure with integrity is sound.

content.meaning_en: A shy, reticent person.
usage_sentences: As an introvert, he prefers quiet evenings at home to large social gatherings.
Being an introvert doesn't mean you can't be a good leader.
content.note: An introvert isn't necessarily shy, but rather recharges energy through solitude and quiet, preferring less external stimulation and deeper social interactions.
content.origin: From German, from Latin 'intro-' (to the inside) and 'vertere' (to turn).

content.meaning_en: A person who intrudes, especially into a building with criminal intent.
usage_sentences: The security alarm went off when the intruder broke into the house.
She felt like an intruder at the private family meeting.
content.note: An intruder signifies an unwelcome presence, entering without permission. Their intent is often criminal, violating boundaries and personal space.

content.meaning_en: An animal lacking a backbone.
usage_sentences: Insects, spiders, and worms are all examples of invertebrates.
Over 95% of animal species are invertebrates.
content.note: A fascinating fun fact: an astounding 95% of all animal species on Earth are invertebrates, from tiny insects to massive squids, lacking a backbone.

content.meaning_en: A formal or systematic inquiry or examination into something.
usage_sentences: The police have launched a full investigation into the robbery.
