The results of the scientific investigation will be published next month.
content.note: An investigation is a systematic quest for truth, meticulously gathering evidence and examining facts to uncover what happened, often in a legal or scientific context.
content.origin: From Latin 'investigare', meaning 'to track, trace out'.

content.meaning_en: A person who supervises candidates during an examination.
usage_sentences: The invigilator instructed the students to stop writing when the time was up.
An invigilator walked around the exam hall to prevent cheating.
content.note: An invigilator supervises examinations, ensuring fair play and adherence to rules. Their presence helps maintain the integrity and validity of academic assessments.
content.origin: From the verb 'invigilate', from Latin 'invigilare' (to watch over).

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A list of goods sent or services provided, with a statement of the sum due for these; a bill. (Verb) - Send an invoice to.
usage_sentences: Please pay the amount due on the invoice within 30 days.
Our accounts department will invoice you for the work we have completed.
content.note: An invoice is a detailed commercial document listing goods or services and the amount due. It serves as a formal request for payment, not just a casual bill.

content.meaning_en: Done without will or conscious control.
usage_sentences: Blinking and breathing are involuntary actions.
He let out an involuntary cry of pain when he touched the hot stove.
content.note: Involuntary actions occur without conscious effort, like blinking or a reflex. They are typically automatic responses, often essential for bodily functions or survival.

content.meaning_en: Impossible to harm or damage.
usage_sentences: In the myth, the hero Achilles was invulnerable except for his heel.
The fortress was believed to be invulnerable to attack.
content.note: To be invulnerable means to be entirely immune to harm or damage. It implies an impenetrable strength, resilience, or even mythical protection.

content.meaning_en: Supply water to (land or crops) to help growth, typically by means of channels.
usage_sentences: Farmers use canals to irrigate their fields in the dry season.
The new dam will provide water to irrigate thousands of acres of land.
content.note: To irrigate is to deliberately supply water to land or crops, especially in dry areas, essential for agriculture and transforming barren landscapes into productive ones.

content.meaning_en: The supply of water to land or crops to help growth, typically by means of channels.
usage_sentences: Good irrigation is essential for agriculture in arid regions.
The government has invested in new irrigation projects.
content.note: Irrigation is the controlled application of water to assist in the growth of agricultural crops, typically via engineered systems, pivotal for food security.

content.meaning_en: A piece of land surrounded by water.
usage_sentences: They spent their vacation on a beautiful tropical island.
Great Britain is a large island off the coast of mainland Europe.
content.note: An island often embodies a sense of remoteness, a unique ecosystem, or a sanctuary, geographically distinct and separated by water from larger landmasses.

content.meaning_en: A small island.
usage_sentences: We took a small boat to a deserted islet for a picnic.
The bay was dotted with dozens of tiny, rocky islets.
content.note: An islet is merely a very small island, often uninhabited and perhaps little more than a rock outcropping, distinguishing it by its diminutive size.
content.origin: From Old French 'islette', a diminutive of 'isle' (island).

content.meaning_en: Far away from other places, buildings, or people; remote.
usage_sentences: He grew up in an isolated farmhouse miles from the nearest town.
After the argument, she felt very isolated from her friends.
content.note: Isolated can describe physical separation, being far from others. It also speaks to a state of emotional detachment or loneliness, feeling apart from connections.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Traveling from place to place. (Noun) - A person who travels from place to place.
usage_sentences: The itinerant farm workers moved from region to region following the harvest.
He lived an itinerant lifestyle, never staying in one place for more than a few months.
content.note: "Itinerant" describes someone who travels from place to place, often for work or a nomadic lifestyle, signifying a lack of a fixed home or settled routine.

content.meaning_en: A planned route or journey.
usage_sentences: The travel agent helped us plan our itinerary for our trip to Europe.
According to the itinerary, we will be visiting Rome on Tuesday.
content.note: An itinerary is a meticulously planned route or schedule for a journey. It outlines stops, timings, and activities, ensuring an organized travel experience.

content.meaning_en: The activity of gathering, assessing, creating, and presenting news and information.
usage_sentences: She studied journalism at university and now works for a major newspaper.
Freedom of the press is a fundamental principle of journalism.
content.note: Journalism is the essential practice of informing the public by gathering, evaluating, and presenting news. It plays a critical role in fostering an informed society.

content.meaning_en: A person who writes for newspapers, magazines, or news websites or prepares news to be broadcast.
usage_sentences: An investigative journalist uncovered a major political scandal.
The journalist was sent to report on the war from the front lines.
content.note: A journalist is a truth-seeker and storyteller, informing the public on current events and issues. Their work is vital for transparency and accountability.

content.meaning_en: An act of traveling from one place to another.
usage_sentences: They embarked on a long journey across the country.
Life itself can be seen as a journey of discovery.
content.note: A journey is not merely travel; it often implies a transformative experience, a passage through challenges, or significant personal growth, literal or metaphorical.
content.origin: From Old French 'jornee', meaning 'a day's travel'.

content.meaning_en: A feeling of great pleasure and happiness.
usage_sentences: Her face was filled with joy when she saw her family.
The birth of their first child brought them immense joy.
content.note: Joy is a profound and often sustained feeling of great pleasure and happiness, deeper than fleeting amusement, stemming from contentment or fulfillment.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A public official appointed to decide cases in a court of law. (Verb) - Form an opinion or conclusion about.
usage_sentences: The judge sentenced the guilty man to five years in prison.
You shouldn't judge a book by its cover.
content.note: Beyond judging legal cases, to "judge" is to form a critical opinion or evaluation, which can be subjective and potentially influenced by personal biases.

content.meaning_en: The judicial authorities of a country; judges collectively.
usage_sentences: An independent judiciary is a cornerstone of a democratic society.
The judiciary is one of the three branches of government.
content.note: The judiciary, composed of a nation's judges, stands as the branch of government interpreting and applying laws, upholding the constitution and ensuring justice.

content.meaning_en: The theory or philosophy of law.
usage_sentences: He is a professor of jurisprudence at the law school.
The case raised complex questions of jurisprudence.
content.note: Jurisprudence delves into the fundamental theories and philosophy of law, exploring its nature, purpose, and relationship to justice, ethics, and society.

content.meaning_en: A body of people (typically twelve in number) sworn to give a verdict in a legal case on the basis of evidence submitted to them in court.
usage_sentences: The jury found the defendant not guilty.
It took the jury several hours to reach a verdict.
content.note: A jury comprises ordinary citizens tasked with impartially weighing evidence to deliver a verdict. It’s a cornerstone of democratic justice, ensuring community involvement.

content.meaning_en: (Of a sense) highly developed.
usage_sentences: Dogs have a keen sense of smell.
He has a keen interest in history and visits museums often.
content.note: "Keen" can mean highly developed, as in a keen sense of smell, but also eager and enthusiastic, showing sharp intellect or strong desire, like a keen student.

content.meaning_en: One's family and relations.
usage_sentences: He invited all his kith and kin to the wedding celebration.
Your next of kin must be notified in case of an emergency.
content.note: Kin refers broadly to one's family and relatives, encompassing those connected by blood, marriage, or a deep, inherent sense of belonging.
content.origin: From Old English 'cynn', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: Friends and relations.
usage_sentences: The party was a large affair, with all their kith and kin in attendance.
In times of trouble, you rely on your kith and kin for support.
content.note: "Kith and kin" is an idiom specifically referring to both one's friends (kith) and one's family and relations (kin), encompassing a wider circle of close connections.

content.meaning_en: (Of handwriting or print) clear enough to read.
usage_sentences: Please make sure your handwriting is legible on the exam paper.
The old sign was barely legible after years of weathering.
content.note: Legible writing or print is crucial for effective communication. If it's clear enough to read easily, the message can be readily understood and shared.

content.meaning_en: A piece of equipment consisting of a series of bars or steps between two upright lengths of wood, metal, or rope, used for climbing up or down something.
usage_sentences: He used a ladder to get the cat down from the tree.
She is trying to climb the corporate ladder to a management position.
content.note: A ladder is not just a tool for climbing; it's a powerful metaphor for advancement, hierarchy, or progression, like climbing the 'career ladder.'
content.origin: From Old English 'hlǣder', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A young sheep.
usage_sentences: The little lamb stayed close to its mother in the field.
Mary had a little lamb whose fleece was white as snow.
content.note: A lamb, a young sheep, often symbolizes innocence, purity, and gentleness across various cultures and religious narratives, representing vulnerability.
content.origin: From Old English 'lamb', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: Denoting the second or second mentioned of two people or things.
usage_sentences: Between the book and the movie, I preferred the latter.
In the latter half of the year, the company's profits increased.
content.note: "Latter" refers to the second of two things mentioned, distinct from "former" which denotes the first. Remember: first is former, second is latter.

content.meaning_en: Deserving praise and commendation.
usage_sentences: Her dedication to charity work is truly laudable.
He made a laudable effort to improve his community.
content.note: Laudable actions or qualities are those truly deserving of praise and commendation, recognized for their positive impact, merit, or exemplary nature.

content.meaning_en: Clothes and other articles that have been or are to be washed.
usage_sentences: He spent all of Sunday morning doing the laundry.
Please put your dirty clothes in the laundry basket.
content.note: Laundry represents the recurring cycle of cleaning clothes, a fundamental aspect of hygiene and domestic life, transforming soiled items into fresh ones.
content.origin: From Middle English 'lavendrie', from Latin 'lavare' (to wash).

content.meaning_en: Unwilling to work or use energy.
usage_sentences: He spent a lazy afternoon napping on the sofa.
Don't be lazy; get up and help with the chores.
content.note: Laziness is a reluctance to exert effort. It's distinct from fatigue or seeking rest; it implies an unwillingness to engage in necessary work or activity.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A contract by which one party conveys land, property, services, etc., to another for a specified time, usually in return for a periodic payment. (Verb) - Grant on lease.
usage_sentences: We signed a one-year lease for the apartment.
They decided to lease a car instead of buying one.
content.note: A lease is a contractual agreement granting temporary possession of property in exchange for payment, defining specific terms and responsibilities distinct from ownership.
content.origin: From Old French 'laissier', meaning 'to let, leave'.

content.meaning_en: An amount of money or property left to someone in a will.
usage_sentences: He received a small legacy from his great-aunt.
The artist's true legacy is his incredible body of work.
content.note: A legacy can be a monetary inheritance, but more broadly, it's what one leaves behind for future generations—a lasting impact, reputation, or cultural heritage.
content.origin: From Old French 'legacie', from Latin 'legare' (to bequeath).

content.meaning_en: Permitted by law.
usage_sentences: You should always seek legal advice before signing a contract.
It is not legal to drive without a valid license.
content.note: Legal actions conform to the established rules and laws of society. Being legal ensures fairness, order, and adherence to societal norms and justice.

content.meaning_en: Free time; time not spent working or occupied.
usage_sentences: What do you enjoy doing in your leisure time?
The hotel offers a wide range of leisure facilities, including a pool and a spa.
content.note: Leisure is invaluable free time, consciously chosen for relaxation, hobbies, or personal pursuits, essential for mental well-being, creativity, and rejuvenation.
content.origin: From Old French 'leisir', from Latin 'licere' (to be permitted).

content.meaning_en: Resembling or characteristic of a lion.
usage_sentences: The old king had a majestic, leonine appearance with his great mane of white hair.
He possessed a leonine courage that was admired by all.
content.note: "Leonine" describes characteristics resembling a lion, often evoking strength, majesty, courage, or a powerful, regal bearing and appearance.

content.meaning_en: A person who compiles dictionaries.
usage_sentences: Samuel Johnson was a famous 18th-century lexicographer.
A lexicographer must be meticulous and have a deep love for language.
content.note: A lexicographer meticulously shapes language by defining words, capturing their evolving usage, and preserving their meanings for future generations. It's a foundational role in communication.

content.meaning_en: The art or science of compiling dictionaries.
usage_sentences: The study of lexicography reveals how languages change over time.
He is an expert in the field of lexicography.
content.note: Lexicography is both a science, with systematic rules for definition and usage, and an art, requiring profound linguistic intuition to capture the nuanced life of words.

content.meaning_en: The vocabulary of a person, language, or branch of knowledge.
usage_sentences: The lexicon of computer science includes terms like 'algorithm' and 'bandwidth'.
She has an impressive lexicon for someone her age.
content.note: A lexicon isn't just a list; it's a dynamic system reflecting an individual's thoughts or a community's shared understanding, constantly expanding with new concepts and expressions.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - An advocate of principles of liberty and free will. (Adjective) - Relating to or denoting a political philosophy that upholds liberty as a core principle.
usage_sentences: As a libertarian, he believes in minimal government intervention.
The libertarian party advocates for free markets and individual rights.
content.note: Libertarianism emphasizes individual liberty above all, often advocating minimal government intervention in both economic and personal spheres, a distinct approach from other political ideologies.

content.meaning_en: A short band of tough, flexible, fibrous connective tissue which connects two bones or cartilages or holds together a joint.
usage_sentences: The athlete tore a ligament in his knee during the game.
Strong ligaments are crucial for joint stability.
content.note: Ligaments are crucial for stability, silently working to hold our skeletal structure together. Their strength and flexibility allow movement while preventing dislocation, a vital biomechanical marvel.

content.meaning_en: The focus of public attention.
usage_sentences: The young actor was suddenly thrust into the limelight after his first hit movie.
Some celebrities enjoy being in the limelight, while others prefer a private life.
content.note: To be in the limelight means enduring intense scrutiny, where every action is magnified. It highlights the fleeting nature of fame and the pressure that accompanies public adoration.
content.origin: From 'limelight', a type of stage lighting used in the 19th century.

content.meaning_en: Able to read and write.
usage_sentences: The government's goal is to ensure that every citizen is literate.
You need to be computer literate to find a good job these days.
content.note: Literacy is more than decoding symbols; it's the gateway to knowledge, critical thinking, and participation in a written culture. It empowers individuals and societies alike.

content.meaning_en: Farm animals regarded as an asset.
usage_sentences: The farmer raises cattle, sheep, and other livestock.
A drought can have a devastating impact on livestock.
content.note: Livestock represents both an economic asset and a profound responsibility. Their care and management are integral to agriculture, providing food, fiber, and livelihoods across the globe.
content.origin: A compound of 'live' and 'stock' (in the sense of farm property).

content.meaning_en: Expressed clearly; easy to understand.
usage_sentences: He gave a lucid explanation of the complex scientific theory.
She had a lucid dream where she was aware that she was dreaming.
content.note: Clarity is paramount for effective communication. To be lucid means thinking and speaking with a luminous precision that cuts through ambiguity, making complex ideas accessible to all.

content.meaning_en: Producing a great deal of profit.
usage_sentences: He left his job to start a lucrative online business.
The tech industry can be a very lucrative field for skilled professionals.
content.note: While lucrative pursuits promise financial reward, true wealth often encompasses more than just profit. Sustainable success balances economic gain with ethical practices and social value.

content.meaning_en: The SI unit of luminous flux, equal to the amount of light emitted per second in a unit solid angle of one steradian by a uniform point source of one candela.
usage_sentences: This light bulb has an output of 800 lumens.
When buying a projector, check the lumen rating for brightness.
content.note: A lumen precisely quantifies the total perceived power of light. It's not about brightness per se, but the amount of light an observer sees, fundamental for lighting design.

content.meaning_en: A person who inspires or influences others, especially one prominent in a particular sphere.
usage_sentences: The conference was attended by many luminaries from the world of science.
She is considered a luminary in the field of modern art.
content.note: A luminary shines brightly, not just through their accomplishments, but by illuminating paths for others. They embody influence, guiding thought and action within their domain.

content.meaning_en: A single payment made at a particular time, as opposed to a series of smaller payments or installments.
usage_sentences: He chose to receive his lottery winnings as a lump sum.
The retirement plan offers the option of a lump sum payout.
content.note: A lump sum offers immediate financial finality or opportunity, distinct from installment plans. It often implies a significant, one-time transaction, simplifying complex financial arrangements.

content.meaning_en: Of or relating to the moon.
usage_sentences: The Apollo missions were part of the lunar exploration program.
A lunar eclipse occurs when the Earth passes between the Sun and the Moon.
content.note: Lunar phenomena, from tides to moon phases, have deeply influenced human culture and science for millennia. "Lunar" connects us directly to our celestial neighbor's enduring mystique.

content.meaning_en: Very generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or someone less powerful than oneself.
usage_sentences: The winning team was magnanimous in victory and praised their opponents.
It was magnanimous of him to forgive the person who had wronged him.
content.note: Magnanimity is a powerful act of character, demonstrating greatness of spirit by forgiving foes or being generous to the less powerful. It elevates beyond petty grievances.

content.meaning_en: Extremely beautiful, elaborate, or impressive.
usage_sentences: The palace was filled with magnificent paintings and sculptures.
The view from the mountaintop was absolutely magnificent.
content.note: Magnificent implies a grandeur that inspires awe and wonder. It's not merely beautiful but possesses a scale and impact that leaves a lasting impression, often artfully crafted.

content.meaning_en: Cause or enable (a condition or state of affairs) to continue.
usage_sentences: It is important to maintain a healthy diet and exercise regularly.
Regular maintenance is required to keep the car in good condition.
content.note: To maintain something requires constant effort and vigilance. It's about preserving equilibrium, ensuring continuity, and resisting decay or change to sustain a desired state.
content.origin: From Old French 'maintenir', from Latin 'manu tenere' (to hold in the hand).

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who is dissatisfied and rebellious. (Adjective) - Dissatisfied with the existing state of affairs.
usage_sentences: A small group of malcontents started a protest against the new policy.
He was a malcontent employee who was always complaining about the company.
content.note: A malcontent, often dissatisfied with the status quo, challenges existing systems. While their discontent can fuel rebellion, it can also be a catalyst for necessary social change.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Fail to function normally or satisfactorily. (Noun) - Failure to function normally.
usage_sentences: A software malfunction caused the entire computer system to crash.
The machine began to malfunction due to a faulty part.
content.note: A malfunction reveals the fragility of complex systems. It highlights how minor failures can cascade into significant disruptions, reminding us of the intricate design and interdependence of parts.

content.meaning_en: (Of a metal or other material) able to be hammered or pressed permanently out of shape without breaking or cracking.
usage_sentences: Gold is a malleable metal that can be hammered into very thin sheets.
The minds of young children are malleable and easily influenced.
content.note: Malleability isn't just about physical form; it also describes adaptability. A malleable mind, for example, can be shaped by new ideas without breaking, embracing change and growth.

content.meaning_en: Lack of proper nutrition, caused by not having enough to eat, not eating enough of the right things, or being unable to make use of the food that one does eat.
usage_sentences: Many children in developing countries suffer from malnutrition.
A poor diet can lead to malnutrition even in wealthy nations.
content.note: Malnutrition, a complex global challenge, impacts physical and cognitive development, perpetuating cycles of poverty. It underscores the profound link between food security and human potential.

content.meaning_en: A warm-blooded vertebrate animal of a class that is distinguished by the possession of hair or fur, females secrete milk for the nourishment of the young, and (typically) the birth of live young.
usage_sentences: Humans, dogs, elephants, and whales are all examples of mammals.
One of the defining characteristics of mammals is that they produce milk for their young.
content.note: Mammals showcase incredible diversity, from tiny shrews to giant whales. Their unique traits like mammary glands and hair demonstrate evolutionary success, adapting to nearly every ecosystem.

content.meaning_en: A public declaration of policy and aims, especially one issued before an election by a political party or candidate.
usage_sentences: The political party released its manifesto outlining its plans for the country.
The artist's manifesto explained her vision for a new art movement.
content.note: A manifesto isn't merely a promise; it's a foundational statement of intent, outlining a vision and a plan. It calls for allegiance and sets the terms for a future course of action.

content.meaning_en: A book, document, or piece of music written by hand rather than typed or printed.
usage_sentences: The author submitted the manuscript of her new novel to the publisher.
The museum has a collection of rare medieval manuscripts.
content.note: Manuscripts offer a direct connection to the creator's hand, preserving personal touch and historical context. Before printing, they were unique artifacts, bearing witness to past knowledge and artistry.
content.origin: From medieval Latin 'manuscriptus', from 'manu' (by hand) and 'scriptus' (written).

content.meaning_en: Of, found in, or relating to the sea.
usage_sentences: A marine biologist studies the plants and animals that live in the ocean.
Dolphins and whales are marine mammals.
content.note: The term "marine" encompasses the vast, mysterious, and vital world beneath the waves. It speaks to biodiversity, ecological balance, and the profound impact oceans have on Earth's climate.

content.meaning_en: Relating to war or armed forces.
usage_sentences: Karate and judo are types of martial arts.
The government declared martial law to restore order after the riots.
content.note: Martial arts and law derive from this word, highlighting the disciplined, often strategic, aspects associated with warfare. It speaks to readiness, combat, and military order.
content.origin: From Latin 'martialis', from 'Mars', the Roman god of war.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who is killed because of their religious or other beliefs. (Verb) - Kill (someone) for their beliefs.
usage_sentences: Joan of Arc is considered a martyr by many.
He became a martyr for the cause of freedom.
content.note: A martyr's sacrifice for belief profoundly impacts collective memory, often inspiring movements. Their death isn't an end, but a powerful symbol, immortalizing their conviction and cause.

content.meaning_en: Excessively concerned with material possessions; preoccupied with material rather than spiritual or intellectual things.
usage_sentences: He lives a very materialistic lifestyle, always buying the latest gadgets.
Modern society is often criticized for being too materialistic.
content.note: While often seen negatively, materialism also reflects a pursuit of comfort and status. It highlights the tension between tangible possessions and intangible values like wisdom or happiness.

content.meaning_en: A woman who is the head of a family or tribe.
usage_sentences: The old matriarch ruled over her large family with wisdom and authority.
In elephant herds, the leader is always the oldest female, the matriarch.
content.note: A matriarch wields significant power and influence, guiding her family or community through wisdom and strength. Her role extends beyond authority, often embodying tradition and resilience.

content.meaning_en: The killing of one's mother.
usage_sentences: The defendant was on trial for the crime of matricide.
The story of Orestes in Greek mythology involves matricide.
content.note: Matricide, an act of profound betrayal, represents one of the deepest societal taboos. It signifies a complete breakdown of familial bonds and moral order, often explored in tragedy.

content.meaning_en: Relating to the Middle Ages.
usage_sentences: We visited a medieval castle that was built over 800 years ago.
The museum has an extensive collection of medieval art.
content.note: The Medieval period, often mischaracterized as "dark," was a vibrant era of cultural, architectural, and intellectual development, laying foundations for the modern world.

content.meaning_en: Producing or having a pleasant tune; tuneful.
usage_sentences: The melodious sound of the flute filled the air.
She has a beautiful, melodious singing voice.
content.note: Melodious sounds resonate with our emotions, creating harmony and beauty. It's the quality that makes music enchanting, capable of transcending language and evoking profound feelings.

content.meaning_en: An object kept as a reminder or souvenir of a person or event.
usage_sentences: I kept the seashell as a memento of our trip to the beach.
The photograph was a precious memento of her grandparents.
content.note: A memento isn't just an object; it's a tangible link to memory, holding sentimental value. It evokes stories, emotions, and the presence of past experiences, keeping them alive.

content.meaning_en: A historical account or biography written from personal knowledge or special sources.
usage_sentences: The retired general published a memoir about his time in the army.
Her memoir gives a fascinating insight into the world of politics.
content.note: Unlike a full biography, a memoir often focuses on a specific period or theme from the author's life, offering intimate insights and reflections that shaped their perspective.

content.meaning_en: The branch of science and technology concerned with the properties of metals and their production and purification.
usage_sentences: He studied metallurgy to learn how to extract iron from its ore.
Advances in metallurgy were crucial for the Industrial Revolution.
content.note: Metallurgy is essential to civilization, from ancient tools to modern electronics. It transforms raw elements into materials that build our world, shaping technology and human progress.

content.meaning_en: An extreme fear of germs.
usage_sentences: Due to his microphobia, he washed his hands constantly.
A person with microphobia may avoid public places.
content.note: Microphobia highlights how unseen threats can exert profound psychological control. While hygiene is important, this extreme fear paralyzes individuals, demonstrating fear's irrational power.

content.meaning_en: An optical instrument used for viewing very small objects, such as mineral samples or animal or plant cells, typically magnified several hundred times.
usage_sentences: The biologist used a powerful microscope to observe the cells.
We learned how to use a microscope in our science class.
content.note: The microscope unlocked unseen worlds, revealing intricate cellular structures and microbial life. It fundamentally transformed biology and medicine, expanding our understanding of existence beyond the naked eye.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who migrates to another country, especially in order to find employment or better living conditions. (Adjective) - Migratory.
usage_sentences: Migrant workers often travel long distances to find seasonal jobs.
Many migrant birds fly south for the winter.
content.note: Migrants embody resilience, courageously seeking new opportunities or safety. Their journeys contribute significantly to cultural exchange and economic diversity in their new homes globally.

content.meaning_en: Seasonal movement of animals from one region to another.
usage_sentences: The annual migration of wildebeest across the Serengeti is a spectacular event.
Economic hardship is a major driver of human migration.
content.note: Animal migration is a remarkable testament to instinct and survival, an epic journey driven by seasonal changes. It connects ecosystems and highlights nature's enduring, cyclical rhythms.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Imitate (someone or their actions or words), especially in order to entertain or ridicule. (Adjective) - Imitative. (Noun) - A person skilled in imitating others.
usage_sentences: The comedian was famous for his ability to mimic politicians.
The insect has markings that mimic the eyes of a predator.
content.note: Mimicry is a powerful form of learning and communication, from animal camouflage to human performance. It reveals subtle behavioral nuances, often for humor, adaptation, or critique.

content.meaning_en: Conscious or aware of something.
usage_sentences: Please be mindful of the other guests and keep the noise down.
He is very mindful of his health and eats a balanced diet.
content.note: Being mindful means truly living in the present, paying attention without judgment. It enhances self-awareness and reduces stress, fostering a deeper, more intentional engagement with life.

content.meaning_en: A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.
content.meaning_hi: मानव द्वेषी/मनुष्य जाति से घृणा करनेवाला
usage_sentences: The old misanthrope lived alone and chased away any visitors.
After being betrayed, he became a bitter misanthrope.
content.note: A misanthrope challenges the notion of inherent goodness in humanity. Their aversion, though often rooted in disappointment, invites reflection on societal flaws and human nature itself.

content.meaning_en: A dislike of humankind.
usage_sentences: The main character in the play is consumed by misanthropy.
His cynical novels are full of misanthropy and despair.
content.note: Misanthropy reflects a profound skepticism or disappointment in human nature. While it often leads to isolation, it can also ironically highlight a deep, if frustrated, concern for humanity's betterment.

content.meaning_en: A person who hoards wealth and spends as little money as possible.
usage_sentences: Despite being a millionaire, the old miser lived in poverty.
He's such a miser that he won't even turn on the heating in winter.
content.note: A miser's extreme frugality is often driven by fear or control, not necessity. Their hoarding highlights the complex psychology behind wealth accumulation and its often self-defeating nature.

content.meaning_en: A person who hates marriage.
usage_sentences: As a confirmed misogamist, he vowed to remain a bachelor for life.
Her two failed marriages turned her into a misogamist.
content.note: A misogamist's aversion to marriage often stems from personal experiences or philosophical objections to its perceived constraints. It challenges traditional views on companionship and commitment.

content.meaning_en: A person who dislikes, despises, or is strongly prejudiced against women.
content.meaning_hi: स्त्री द्वेषी/नारी जाति से घृणा करनेवाला
usage_sentences: His misogynist comments caused a public outcry.
The boss was fired for being a misogynist and treating female employees unfairly.
content.note: Misogyny reflects deeply ingrained prejudice, often perpetuating systemic inequality and harm. Recognizing and challenging it is crucial for achieving true gender equality and respect.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Assisting or intended to assist memory. (Noun) - A device such as a pattern of letters, ideas, or associations that assists in remembering something.
usage_sentences: I use a mnemonic to remember the order of the planets.
'Roy G. Biv' is a popular mnemonic for the colors of the rainbow.
content.note: Mnemonics leverage our natural associative abilities, transforming complex information into memorable patterns. They demonstrate the creative power of the mind to simplify recall and enhance learning.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A large crowd of people, especially one that is disorderly and intent on causing trouble or violence. (Verb) - Crowd around (someone) in a disorderly and intimidating way.
usage_sentences: An angry mob gathered outside the courthouse to protest the verdict.
The celebrity was mobbed by fans as soon as he left the hotel.
content.note: A mob signifies a loss of individual accountability within a crowd, capable of both spontaneous chaos and collective violence. It reflects the dark side of group dynamics.
content.origin: Short for 'mobile vulgus', a Latin phrase meaning 'fickle crowd'.

content.meaning_en: Lasting for a very short time; brief.
usage_sentences: There was a momentary pause in the conversation.
For a momentary lapse in concentration, he lost the game.
content.note: Momentary underscores the fleeting nature of time and experience. It reminds us that even profound joy or sorrow are transient, encouraging presence and appreciation for the present instant.

content.meaning_en: A sovereign ruler, especially a king, queen, or emperor.
usage_sentences: Queen Elizabeth II was the longest-reigning monarch in British history.
The monarch butterfly is known for its long migration.
content.note: A monarch embodies sovereignty, often inheriting power and symbolizing national identity. Their reign can represent continuity, tradition, or, historically, absolute authority shaping an entire era.

content.meaning_en: Sovereignty by one person.
usage_sentences: The United Kingdom is a constitutional monarchy.
The French Revolution led to the end of the monarchy in France.
content.note: While often associated with kings/queens, a monarchy can be absolute or constitutional, showing a spectrum of power, from divine right to symbolic head.

content.meaning_en: A building or buildings occupied by monks living under religious vows.
usage_sentences: The old monastery was perched high on a remote mountaintop.
He decided to leave the city and join a monastery.
content.note: More than just buildings, monasteries are self-sufficient communities fostering spiritual discipline, scholarship, and often contribute to local economies and culture.

content.meaning_en: A member of a religious community of men typically living under vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience.
usage_sentences: The monks spent their days in prayer and meditation.
A Buddhist monk in a saffron robe walked silently down the street.
content.note: Monks dedicate their lives to spiritual practice, often in seclusion, contributing to religious wisdom and preserving ancient knowledge across various traditions globally.

content.meaning_en: The practice or state of being married to only one person at a time.
usage_sentences: Monogamy is the most common form of marriage in Western cultures.
Many species of birds practice monogamy and mate for life.
content.note: Monogamy implies serial exclusivity. While often romanticized, it's a specific relational structure, contrasting with other partnership forms, shaping societal norms.

content.meaning_en: A statue, building, or other structure erected to commemorate a famous or notable person or event.
usage_sentences: The Taj Mahal is a magnificent monument to love.
A new monument was built to honor the war veterans.
content.note: Monuments serve as physical markers of collective memory and history. Their removal or reinterpretation can reflect evolving societal values and beliefs over time.

content.meaning_en: The state of being subject to death.
usage_sentences: The high infant mortality rate is a serious concern.
He was suddenly confronted with his own mortality after the accident.
content.note: Mortality is a universal human condition, profoundly influencing philosophy, religion, and art. Acknowledging it can heighten appreciation for life's precious impermanence.

content.meaning_en: The ability to deal with more than one task at the time.
usage_sentences: Working mothers are often experts at multitasking.
Multitasking can sometimes lead to more mistakes and lower quality work.
content.note: Often glorified, true multitasking is rare; brains typically switch rapidly between tasks. It can decrease efficiency and quality for complex cognitive work, creating a busy illusion.

content.meaning_en: Very numerous.
usage_sentences: The city has multitudinous challenges, from traffic to pollution.
He faced multitudinous tasks upon starting his new job.
content.note: This adjective emphasizes an overwhelming, almost uncountable vastness, evoking a sense of immensity far beyond merely "many," like multitudinous stars.

content.meaning_en: A body of a human being or animal that has been embalmed and dried and so preserved for a very long time.
usage_sentences: The museum exhibition featured an ancient Egyptian mummy.
Scientists studied the mummy to learn about life in the past.
content.note: Mummification, both natural and artificial, reveals ancient cultures' beliefs about the afterlife and advanced preservation techniques. Bog bodies are naturally mummified.
content.origin: From medieval Latin 'mummia', from Arabic 'mūmiyā' (embalmed body).

content.meaning_en: A building in which objects of historical, scientific, artistic, or cultural interest are stored and exhibited.
usage_sentences: We spent the afternoon at the natural history museum.
The Louvre in Paris is one of the most famous museums in the world.
content.note: Museums are not just repositories; they are vital institutions for education, cultural preservation, and critical discourse, often shaping public understanding of history.
content.origin: From Latin 'museum', from Greek 'mouseion' (seat of the Muses).

content.meaning_en: Something that is difficult or impossible to understand or explain.
usage_sentences: The disappearance of the ship remains a mystery to this day.
She loves reading mystery novels and trying to solve the crime.
content.note: Mysteries drive human curiosity and scientific inquiry. They challenge our perceptions and expand the boundaries of knowledge, compelling us to seek answers, or accept the unknown.

content.meaning_en: (Of a person or action) showing a lack of experience, wisdom, or judgement.
usage_sentences: She was too naive to realize that he was trying to cheat her.
It was naive of him to trust a complete stranger with his money.
content.note: Naivety implies an innocent lack of worldly knowledge, often charming but potentially vulnerable. It contrasts with ignorance, suggesting innocence rather than willful unawareness.
content.origin: From French 'naïf, naïve', from Latin 'nativus' (native, natural).

content.meaning_en: Excessive interest in or admiration of oneself and one's physical appearance.
usage_sentences: His constant need for attention was a clear sign of his narcissism.
Social media can sometimes encourage narcissism.
content.note: Beyond vanity, narcissism is a complex personality trait involving an inflated sense of self-importance, entitlement, and a lack of empathy, often masking deep insecurity.
content.origin: From Narcissus, a figure in Greek mythology who fell in love with his own reflection.

content.meaning_en: A person who has an excessive interest in or admiration of themselves.
usage_sentences: It is very difficult to have a healthy relationship with a narcissist.
The narcissist constantly steered the conversation back to himself.
content.note: A narcissist often seeks admiration to maintain a fragile self-esteem. Their charming exterior can hide manipulative tendencies and an inability to genuinely connect with others.
content.origin: From Narcissus, a figure in Greek mythology.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Belonging originally to a particular place; indigenous. (Noun) - A person born in a particular place or country.
usage_sentences: The kangaroo is native to Australia.
Although he has lived abroad for years, he is a native of India.
content.note: "Native" carries nuances of belonging and authenticity. It’s distinct from "resident" or "citizen," emphasizing original connection to a place, often with cultural implications.

content.meaning_en: So small or unimportant as to be not worth considering; insignificant.
usage_sentences: The difference in price between the two products was negligible.
The risk of side effects from the medication is negligible.
content.note: Negligible highlights a tiny quantity or effect that can be safely ignored in calculations or assessments, implying an inconsequential impact on the larger system.

content.meaning_en: A district, especially one of a town or city, regarded as a community.
usage_sentences: They live in a quiet, friendly neighbourhood.
The new park will be a great asset for the entire neighbourhood.
content.note: A neighbourhood is more than just geography; it's a social construct. Shared identity, local interactions, and collective memory define its unique character and community spirit.

content.meaning_en: A physician who specializes in nephrology.
usage_sentences: The patient with kidney failure was under the care of a nephrologist.
A nephrologist treats diseases related to the kidneys.
content.note: A nephrologist specializes in the intricate functions and diseases of the kidneys, vital organs for filtering waste and maintaining fluid balance in the body.

content.meaning_en: The practice among those with power or influence of favoring relatives or friends, especially by giving them jobs.
usage_sentences: He was accused of nepotism after hiring his unqualified son for a top position.
Nepotism is a form of corruption that undermines fairness.
content.note: Nepotism undermines meritocracy and fairness, often leading to resentment and decreased morale. It prioritizes personal connections over competence in professional settings.

content.meaning_en: A physician skilled in the diagnosis and treatment of disease of the nervous system.
usage_sentences: She was referred to a neurologist after experiencing persistent headaches.
A neurologist treats conditions like epilepsy, stroke, and Parkinson's disease.
content.note: A neurologist unravels the complexities of the brain, spinal cord, and nerves, diagnosing conditions like strokes, epilepsy, and Parkinson's, crucial for cognitive function.

content.meaning_en: The branch of medicine or biology that deals with the anatomy, functions, and organic disorders of nerves and the nervous system.
usage_sentences: He is a leading expert in the field of neurology.
The hospital has a renowned neurology department.
content.note: Neurology explores the intricate network governing thought, movement, and sensation. It bridges anatomy with clinical practice, seeking to understand and treat nervous system disorders.

content.meaning_en: The scientific study of the nervous system.
usage_sentences: Neuroscience is a rapidly advancing field with many new discoveries.
She is pursuing a PhD in cognitive neuroscience.
content.note: Neuroscience delves into how the brain works, from molecular levels to complex behaviors. It's a vast interdisciplinary field, revealing secrets of consciousness, memory, and perception.

content.meaning_en: The devising or choosing of names for things, especially in a science or other discipline.
usage_sentences: The botanical nomenclature is governed by a strict set of rules.
Understanding the correct chemical nomenclature is essential for a chemist.
content.note: Nomenclature ensures clarity and precision in communication. Standardized naming systems, like in biology, prevent confusion and facilitate global scientific understanding and collaboration.

content.meaning_en: A sentimental longing or wistful affection for the past, typically for a period or place with happy personal associations.
usage_sentences: Looking at old family photos filled him with a sense of nostalgia.
The song was pure nostalgia, taking him back to his college days.
content.note: Nostalgia is often bittersweet, a longing for idealized past moments. It's a powerful emotion that can both comfort us and sometimes distort historical memory.

content.meaning_en: Famous or well known, typically for some bad quality or deed.
usage_sentences: Al Capone was a notorious gangster in the 1920s.
The politician is notorious for his dishonesty.
content.note: "Notorious" is distinctly negative. While "famous" can be for good or ill, "notorious" exclusively implies a widespread reputation for infamy, often for illicit or scandalous actions.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Having no legal or binding force; invalid. (Noun) - Nothing; zero.
usage_sentences: Without the owner's signature, the contract is null and void.
The result of the calculation was null.
content.note: "Null" signifies absence, invalidity, or zero value. In programming, a "null" value indicates a deliberate lack of an object, distinct from an empty string or zero.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Not discovered or known about; uncertain. (Verb) - Keep from being seen; conceal.
usage_sentences: He was an obscure poet whose work was only discovered after his death.
The heavy fog threatened to obscure our view of the road.
content.note: "Obscure" carries a dual meaning: something unknown or hidden, or the act of hiding. A poet might be obscure, or clouds might obscure the sun.

content.meaning_en: A room or building housing an astronomical telescope or other scientific equipment for the study of natural phenomena.
usage_sentences: Astronomers at the observatory discovered a new comet.
The mountain-top location provides the observatory with clear views of the sky.
content.note: Observatories are windows to the cosmos, equipped to reveal distant galaxies and cosmic events. They are crucial for astronomical research and public engagement with science.

content.meaning_en: A person's job or profession.
usage_sentences: Please state your name, age, and occupation.
Teaching is a very rewarding occupation.
content.note: "Occupation" can also refer to the act of occupying a space or territory. This dual meaning, either a livelihood or a forceful taking, adds crucial contextual nuance.
content.origin: From Latin 'occupatio(n-)', from the verb 'occupare' (to seize).

content.meaning_en: A plane figure with eight straight sides and eight angles.
usage_sentences: A standard stop sign has the shape of an octagon.
The building was designed with an octagon at its center.
content.note: The prefix "oct-" consistently denotes "eight," seen in "octopus" and "octogenarian." An octagon's distinct shape appears in diverse architecture, from ancient structures to modern signs.

content.meaning_en: A person who is from 80 to 89 years old.
usage_sentences: Despite being an octogenarian, he still enjoys a game of tennis.
The sprightly octogenarian walked five miles every day.
content.note: An octogenarian represents a significant milestone of longevity, embodying decades of experience and perspective. It implies a specific age range, unlike general terms for elderly.

content.meaning_en: A cephalopod mollusk with eight sucker-bearing arms, a soft body, and no internal skeleton.
usage_sentences: The octopus is a highly intelligent marine animal.
An octopus can change its color to blend in with its surroundings.
content.note: Octopuses are incredibly intelligent, masters of camouflage and problem-solving, with three hearts and blue blood. Their complex behavior highlights invertebrate cognitive abilities.

content.meaning_en: Not located in the center; away from the center.
usage_sentences: The picture on the wall was slightly off-centre.
He has a quirky, off-centre sense of humor.
content.note: "Off-centre" implies a deliberate or unintentional displacement from the middle. It can suggest asymmetry, imbalance, or a unique perspective, challenging conventional alignment.

content.meaning_en: Having unlimited power; able to do anything.
usage_sentences: In many religions, God is described as an omnipotent being.
The dictator ruled the country as if he were omnipotent.
content.note: This term describes absolute, boundless power, often attributed to deities. Conceptually, true omnipotence raises paradoxes, like whether an omnipotent being can create an unliftable stone.

content.meaning_en: Knowing everything.
usage_sentences: The novel is told from the perspective of an omniscient narrator.
It is impossible for any human to be truly omniscient.
content.note: Omniscience refers to infinite knowledge, typically a divine attribute. In literature, an omniscient narrator provides a comprehensive, god-like perspective on all characters and events.
content.origin: From late Latin 'omniscient-', from 'omnis' (all) and 'scire' (to know).

content.meaning_en: Present everywhere simultaneously.
usage_sentences: In today's world, the influence of technology seems to be omnipresent.
God is believed by some to be omnipresent.
content.note: Omnipresence describes being universally present at all times. It denotes boundless presence, distinct from merely widespread, often used in theological or philosophical contexts.

content.meaning_en: An animal or person that eats food of both plant and animal origin.
usage_sentences: Bears and humans are examples of omnivores.
An omnivore's diet is varied, including fruits, vegetables, and meat.
content.note: Omnivores demonstrate dietary flexibility, adapting to diverse food sources. Humans are classic omnivores, showcasing the survival advantage of a varied diet.

content.meaning_en: Not able to be seen through; not transparent.
usage_sentences: The frosted glass in the bathroom door is opaque for privacy.
His legal jargon was dense and opaque, making it hard to understand.
content.note: Opaque describes a lack of transparency, blocking light completely. Figuratively, it can mean obscure or difficult to understand, as in "opaque prose."

content.meaning_en: A person who tends to be hopeful and confident about the future or the success of something.
usage_sentences: Despite the challenges, she remains an eternal optimist.
An optimist sees the opportunity in every difficulty.
content.note: An optimist often sees challenges as opportunities. While generally positive, extreme optimism can sometimes lead to underestimating risks or ignoring potential pitfalls.

content.meaning_en: A public speaker, especially one who is eloquent or skilled.
usage_sentences: Martin Luther King Jr. was a powerful and inspiring orator.
The skilled orator held the audience's attention for the entire speech.
content.note: An orator wields words to persuade, inspire, or move an audience. Their skill lies not just in content, but in delivery, rhythm, and the emotional resonance of their speech.

content.meaning_en: An intentional planting of trees or shrubs that is maintained for food production.
usage_sentences: They spent the afternoon picking apples in the orchard.
The farm has a large cherry orchard that is popular in the spring.
content.note: Orchards are cultivated ecosystems focused on fruit yield. They require careful planning, pollination, and pruning, showcasing humanity's long history of agricultural innovation.

content.meaning_en: A large instrumental ensemble typical of classical music, that combines instruments from different families.
usage_sentences: The symphony orchestra performed Beethoven's Fifth Symphony.
She plays the violin in the city's youth orchestra.
content.note: An orchestra embodies harmony through diversity. Different instrument families — strings, woodwinds, brass, percussion — unite under a conductor to create a cohesive, powerful sound.
content.origin: From Greek 'orkhēstra', the space where the chorus danced in a theater.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - An authoritative command, direction, or instruction. (Verb) - Give an authoritative direction or instruction to do something.
usage_sentences: The general gave the order to attack.
Please put the books in alphabetical order.
content.note: "Order" has many meanings: sequence, command, calm, or a group. Distinguishing between "to order" (command) and "in order" (sequence) is key for clarity.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A child whose parents are dead. (Verb) - Cause a child to become an orphan.
usage_sentences: The charity provides housing and education for orphans.
He was left an orphan at a very young age.
content.note: The term "orphan" signifies profound loss and vulnerability. It highlights the protective role of parents and the societal responsibility to care for children without them.

content.meaning_en: Conforming to what is traditionally accepted as right or true; established and approved.
usage_sentences: He holds very orthodox views on religion and society.
The doctor first tried several orthodox treatments before suggesting surgery.
content.note: "Orthodox" implies adherence to established beliefs or practices, often associated with religious traditions or conventional thought. It contrasts with heterodox or unconventional approaches.

content.meaning_en: Fail to notice (something).
usage_sentences: In his haste, he managed to overlook a crucial detail.
Our hotel room balcony will overlook the sea.
content.note: "Overlook" means to miss something, but can also mean to have a view from above, or to tolerate something. The context is crucial for its meaning; failing to notice is distinct from a scenic overlook.

content.meaning_en: Bury or drown beneath a huge mass of something, especially water or emotion.
usage_sentences: She was overwhelmed with gratitude for all the help she received.
Don't let the amount of work overwhelm you; just take it one task at a time.
content.note: Overwhelm suggests being submerged beyond capacity, physically or emotionally. It conveys a sense of being overpowered, losing control amidst a deluge of sensations or tasks.
content.origin: From Middle English, from 'over' and 'whelmen' (to turn upside down).

content.meaning_en: The belief that war and violence are unjustifiable and that disputes should be settled by peaceful means.
usage_sentences: He was a strong advocate of pacifism and non-violent protest.
Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy was deeply rooted in pacifism.
content.note: Pacifism is a principled stance against violence, advocating non-violent resistance and diplomacy. It challenges the conventional wisdom of war as a solution to conflict.

content.meaning_en: A person who believes in pacifism or is opposed to war or to violence of any kind.
usage_sentences: As a pacifist, he refused to join the army.
The protest was led by a group of dedicated pacifists.
content.note: A pacifist actively advocates for peace, often through non-violent protest and diplomacy. Their commitment stems from a deep conviction that violence is never the answer.

content.meaning_en: Quell the anger, agitation, or excitement of.
usage_sentences: The mother tried to pacify her crying baby with a toy.
The diplomat's speech was intended to pacify the angry crowd.
content.note: To pacify is to calm or soothe, often by appeasement. It can imply a gentle resolution or, more negatively, a forceful suppression of dissent or unrest.
content.origin: From Old French 'pacifier', from Latin 'pax' (peace) and '-ficare' (to make).

content.meaning_en: A formal agreement between individuals or parties.
usage_sentences: The two rival companies signed a pact to work together on the project.
They made a pact as children to always remain friends.
content.note: A pact signifies a formal, binding agreement, often carrying weight beyond a simple promise. It implies mutual commitment and shared responsibility for its terms.

content.meaning_en: A solution or remedy for all ills or difficulties.
usage_sentences: He believes that education is the panacea for all of society's problems.
Unfortunately, there is no panacea that will make you rich overnight.
content.note: A panacea promises a universal cure, yet few problems truly have one singular solution. It's often an elusive ideal, suggesting a magical remedy for all woes.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - (of a disease) prevalent over a whole country or the world. (Adjective) - An outbreak of a pandemic disease.
usage_sentences: The 1918 flu pandemic was one of the deadliest in history.
Health organizations are constantly monitoring for potential pandemic threats.
content.note: A pandemic signifies a disease outbreak spanning entire countries or even the globe. It reflects widespread impact and collective societal challenge, requiring global cooperation.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - Sudden uncontrollable fear or anxiety, often causing wildly unthinking behavior. (Verb) - Feel or cause to feel panic.
usage_sentences: When the fire alarm rang, there was a moment of panic in the theater.
Don't panic, just stay calm and walk to the nearest exit.
content.note: Panic is an intense, sudden fear that can overwhelm reason, leading to impulsive, unthinking actions. It can grip individuals or masses, disrupting normal thought processes.
content.origin: From Greek 'panikos', relating to the god Pan, who was said to cause groundless fear.

content.meaning_en: An unbroken view of the whole region surrounding an observer.
usage_sentences: From the top of the tower, you can see a stunning panorama of the city.
The book provides a panorama of European history.
content.note: A panorama offers an expansive, uninterrupted vista, presenting a complete sweep of the surrounding landscape. It captures the grandeur and breadth of a scene.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Breathe with short, quick breaths, typically from exertion or excitement. (Noun) - A short, quick breath.
usage_sentences: After running up the stairs, he was panting heavily.
The dog sat in the shade, its tongue out, panting in the heat.
content.note: To pant is to breathe rapidly and shallowly, often due to exertion or intense emotion. The sound of a pant signifies effort or excitement, a quick, audible gasp.
content.origin: From Old French 'pantaisier', possibly from Greek 'phantasioun' (to have visions).

content.meaning_en: Independent photographers who take pictures of high-profile people, typically without their consent.
usage_sentences: The celebrity was surrounded by a swarm of paparazzi as she left the restaurant.
She sued the paparazzi for invading her privacy.
content.note: Paparazzi are independent photographers who pursue public figures, often capturing candid shots without consent. Their relentless pursuit raises questions about privacy and media ethics.
content.origin: From 'Paparazzo', the name of a news photographer in the Italian film La Dolce Vita.

content.meaning_en: An organism that lives in or on another organism (its host) and benefits by deriving nutrients at the host's expense.
usage_sentences: A tick is a parasite that feeds on the blood of animals.
He called his lazy brother a parasite because he lived off their parents' money.
content.note: A parasite thrives by feeding off a host, benefiting at the host's detriment. This relationship highlights a stark imbalance, where one organism exploits another for survival.
content.origin: From Greek 'parasitos', meaning '(person) eating at another's table'.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - The release of a prisoner temporarily or permanently before the completion of a sentence, on the promise of good behavior. (Verb) - Release (a prisoner) on parole.
usage_sentences: He was released from prison on parole after serving ten years.
The board denied his request for parole.
content.note: Parole is a conditional release from prison, trusting the individual to maintain good behavior. It's not freedom, but a supervised transition back into society, dependent on conduct.
content.origin: From French 'parole', meaning 'word, speech' (in the sense of 'word of honor').

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A government authority or licence conferring a right or title for a set period, especially the sole right to exclude others from making, using, or selling an invention.
usage_sentences: The inventor filed a patent for her new device.
The company holds several patents on its technology.
content.note: A patent grants an inventor exclusive rights to their creation for a set period. It's a legal shield, protecting innovation and preventing others from unauthorized use, sale, or production.
content.origin: From Old French 'lettre patente' (open letter), from Latin 'patere' (to be open).

content.meaning_en: The science of the causes and effects of diseases.
usage_sentences: The pathology report confirmed that the tumor was benign.
He is a professor of pathology at the medical school.
content.note: Pathology delves into the causes and effects of diseases, examining cellular changes and bodily responses. It's crucial for diagnosis and understanding illness at a fundamental level.

content.meaning_en: The male head of a family or tribe.
usage_sentences: As the patriarch of the family, his decision was final.
The old patriarch was respected by everyone in the community.
content.note: A patriarch is the authoritative male head of a family or group. This role often carries significant traditional power and responsibility, guiding descendants or members.

content.meaning_en: The killing of one's father.
usage_sentences: In the ancient Greek myth, Oedipus unknowingly commits patricide.
He was convicted of the horrific crime of patricide.
content.note: Patricide is the shocking and specific act of killing one's own father. It's a crime deeply rooted in family betrayal, carrying immense social and psychological weight.

content.meaning_en: Relating to or based on relationship to the father or descent through the male line.
usage_sentences: Many traditional societies have a patrilineal system of inheritance.
In a patrilineal culture, family names are passed down from father to son.
content.note: Patrilineal systems trace descent and inheritance exclusively through the male line. This tradition shapes family names, property, and lineage in many cultures.

content.meaning_en: Property inherited from one's father or male ancestor.
usage_sentences: He spent his entire patrimony on risky investments.
The ancient castle was part of his family's patrimony.
content.note: Patrimony refers to an inheritance specifically from one's father or male ancestors. It can be property, but also cultural heritage, passed down through generations.

content.meaning_en: A person who vigorously supports their country and is prepared to defend it against enemies or detractors.
usage_sentences: The soldiers were hailed as heroes and patriots.
A true patriot is one who is loyal to their country at all times.
content.note: A patriot passionately supports and defends their country, often willing to sacrifice for its well-being. Their loyalty is deep, standing against threats and criticisms.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Keep watch over (an area) by regularly walking or travelling around in it in order to maintain order or security. (Noun) - A person or group of people sent out to keep watch over an area.
usage_sentences: The security guard has to patrol the building every hour.
A police patrol car was seen in the neighborhood.
content.note: To patrol is to systematically monitor an area for security or order. Whether a lone guard or a group, a patrol's presence deters trouble and ensures safety through vigilance.

content.meaning_en: The method and practice of teaching, especially as an academic subject or theoretical concept.
usage_sentences: The new teacher was trained in the latest methods of pedagogy.
His pedagogy focuses on interactive and student-centered learning.
content.note: Pedagogy is the art and science of teaching, exploring methods and practices to facilitate learning. It's not just what to teach, but critically, how to teach effectively.

content.meaning_en: A punishment imposed or incurred for a breach of law, rule, or contract.
usage_sentences: The penalty for speeding is a heavy fine.
In football, a foul inside the box results in a penalty kick.
content.note: A penalty is a consequence exacted for violating a rule, law, or agreement. It serves as a deterrent and a form of justice, ensuring accountability for transgressions.

content.meaning_en: A piece of land almost surrounded by water or projecting out into a body of water.
usage_sentences: The state of Florida is a large peninsula.
The Korean Peninsula is located in East Asia.
content.note: A peninsula is a distinctive landform, almost entirely encircled by water, yet connected to the mainland. This geographical feature creates unique coastlines and ecosystems.

content.meaning_en: Persistence in doing something despite difficulty or delay in achieving success.
usage_sentences: With hard work and perseverance, he eventually achieved his goal.
Perseverance is the key to success in any field.
content.note: Perseverance is the unwavering resolve to continue despite obstacles, setbacks, or delays. It embodies a tenacious spirit, pushing through difficulty until success is achieved.

content.meaning_en: People employed in an organization or engaged in an organized undertaking such as military service.
usage_sentences: All personnel are required to attend the safety training.
The company is hiring new personnel for its marketing department.
content.note: Personnel refers collectively to the people employed by an organization or engaged in a specific undertaking. It often implies a professional, organized group crucial to operations.

content.meaning_en: A person who tends to see the worst aspect of things or believe that the worst will happen.
usage_sentences: A pessimist sees the difficulty in every opportunity.
Don't be such a pessimist; try to look on the bright side.
content.note: A pessimist consistently anticipates the worst outcome, often seeing challenges rather than opportunities. Their perspective can shape their reality, fostering a sense of gloom.

content.meaning_en: A substance used for destroying insects or other organisms harmful to cultivated plants or to animals.
usage_sentences: Farmers spray pesticides on their crops to protect them from insects.
Organic farming avoids the use of synthetic pesticides.
content.note: A pesticide is a chemical agent designed to eliminate organisms harmful to crops or animals. While protecting agriculture, its use raises concerns about environmental impact and health.

content.meaning_en: A person who seeks to promote the welfare of others, especially by the generous donation of money to good causes.
usage_sentences: The wealthy philanthropist donated millions to build a new hospital.
She is a well-known philanthropist and supporter of the arts.
content.note: A philanthropist actively promotes human welfare, often through substantial charitable donations. Their generosity aims to improve society, driven by a desire for widespread good.

content.meaning_en: The desire to promote the welfare of others, expressed especially by the generous donation of money to good causes.
usage_sentences: The foundation is dedicated to philanthropy and supports various charities.
His act of philanthropy has helped thousands of people.
content.note: Philanthropy is the practice of promoting human welfare, typically through generous giving to good causes. It embodies a 'love for humanity,' translating compassion into tangible aid.

content.meaning_en: A person who likes, admires, and supports women.
usage_sentences: As a true philogynist, he actively campaigned for women's rights.
His writings show him to be a philogynist, celebrating the strength of female characters.
content.note: A philogynist is someone who likes, admires, and actively supports women. This positive disposition stands in stark contrast to misogyny, valuing and respecting women.

content.meaning_en: A person engaged or learned in philosophy, especially as an academic discipline.
usage_sentences: Socrates and Plato were ancient Greek philosophers.
The philosopher pondered the meaning of life.
content.note: A philosopher explores fundamental questions about existence, knowledge, values, and reason. They seek wisdom and critically examine beliefs, shaping intellectual thought across ages.

content.meaning_en: An extreme or irrational fear of or aversion to something.
usage_sentences: He has a phobia of spiders and cannot even look at a picture of one.
Claustrophobia is a common phobia involving the fear of enclosed spaces.
content.note: A phobia is an intense, often irrational fear or aversion to a specific object or situation. It can profoundly impact daily life, despite often having no real danger.

content.meaning_en: The branch of linguistics that deals with the sounds of speech and their production, and acoustic properties.
usage_sentences: Studying phonetics can help you improve your pronunciation in a foreign language.
Phonetics is the science of speech sounds.
content.note: Phonetics is the study of speech sounds: how they're produced, their physical properties, and how they're perceived. It dissects the very building blocks of spoken language.

content.meaning_en: A person qualified to practice medicine; a doctor.
usage_sentences: You should consult a physician if your symptoms persist.
She is a highly respected physician specializing in internal medicine.
content.note: A physician is a qualified medical professional, dedicated to diagnosing and treating illness, and maintaining health. They combine scientific knowledge with compassionate patient care.
content.origin: From Old French 'fisicien', from 'fisique' (art of healing).

content.meaning_en: The branch of biology that deals with the normal functions of living organisms and their parts.
usage_sentences: He is studying human physiology to understand how the body works.
Plant physiology is concerned with the life processes of plants.
content.note: Physiology investigates how living organisms and their parts function normally. It explores the intricate mechanisms that sustain life, from cellular processes to organ systems.

content.meaning_en: Treatment to restore, maintain, and make the most of a patient’s mobility, function, and well-being.
usage_sentences: After the surgery, he needed physiotherapy to regain strength in his leg.
Physiotherapy can help with a wide range of injuries and conditions.
content.note: Physiotherapy employs physical methods to restore and maximize a patient's movement, function, and well-being. It empowers recovery through therapeutic exercise and manual techniques.

content.meaning_en: The twelfth sign of the zodiac, which the sun enters about February 19.
usage_sentences: Her birthday is in early March, so her zodiac sign is Pisces.
Pisces is represented by two fish swimming in opposite directions.
content.note: Pisces, the twelfth zodiac sign, is represented by two fish swimming in opposite directions. It marks the end of the astrological year, symbolizing transition and duality.

content.meaning_en: Fish-eating.
usage_sentences: Dolphins, penguins, and kingfishers are all piscivorous animals.
The fossilized remains suggest it was a large, piscivorous dinosaur.
content.note: Piscivorous describes animals whose diet primarily consists of fish. This specialized feeding strategy is common in many aquatic and semi-aquatic predators, like herons or otters.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A solemn promise or undertaking. (Verb) - Commit (oneself or one's organization) to a course of action.
usage_sentences: The students made a pledge to keep their school clean.
The company pledged to donate one million dollars to the charity.
content.note: A pledge is a solemn promise or firm commitment, binding one to a specific action or loyalty. It signifies a serious undertaking, often publicly declared with conviction.
content.origin: From Old French 'plege', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: An abundance.
usage_sentences: The harvest festival celebrates the plentitude of the earth.
The library offers a plentitude of books on every conceivable subject.
content.note: Plentitude denotes a state of abundance or ample supply, suggesting richness and sufficiency. It implies more than enough, a generous and bountiful existence.

content.meaning_en: A person who fits and repairs the pipes and fittings of water supply, sanitation, or heating systems.
usage_sentences: We had to call a plumber to fix the leaky faucet.
The plumber installed a new water heater in our house.
content.note: A plumber specializes in installing and repairing vital water, sanitation, and heating systems. Their work is crucial for modern hygiene and comfort, keeping our essential utilities flowing.
content.origin: From Old French 'plommier', from Latin 'plumbum' (lead), as pipes were once made of lead.

content.meaning_en: A small platform on which a person may stand to be heard or to conduct an orchestra.
usage_sentences: The speaker stood at the podium to address the audience.
The top three athletes stood on the winner's podium to receive their medals.
content.note: A podium is an elevated platform providing visibility and authority for a speaker or conductor. It marks a focal point, drawing attention to the individual presenting or leading.

content.meaning_en: The activities associated with the governance of a country or area.
usage_sentences: He decided to enter politics to serve the public.
Office politics can make the workplace very unpleasant.
content.note: Politics encompasses the complex activities of governing, involving power, policy, and public affairs. It shapes societal structures and resource distribution, influencing every citizen's life.

content.meaning_en: A person who practices polygamy.
usage_sentences: In some cultures, it was common for a king to be a polygamist.
The leader of the sect was a polygamist with several wives.
content.note: A polygamist is an individual who practices polygamy, having multiple spouses simultaneously. This marital structure contrasts sharply with monogamy and is illegal in many nations.

content.meaning_en: A plane figure with at least three straight sides and angles, and typically five or more.
usage_sentences: Triangles, squares, and pentagons are all types of polygon.
The teacher taught the students how to calculate the area of a polygon.
content.note: A polygon is a closed two-dimensional shape formed by straight line segments, with at least three sides. Its name, 'poly-gon,' literally means 'many angles.'

content.meaning_en: A person who believes in or worships more than one god.
usage_sentences: The ancient Greeks and Romans were polytheists.
A polytheist worships a pantheon of different gods and goddesses.
content.note: A polytheist believes in or worships multiple gods, each often presiding over different aspects of life or nature. This contrasts with monotheism's singular divine entity.

content.meaning_en: Having a large population.
usage_sentences: China is the world's most populous country.
The city grew into a populous metropolitan area.
content.note: Populous describes a region or area characterized by a very large population. It indicates a high density of inhabitants, often leading to specific social and environmental dynamics.

content.meaning_en: A town or city with a harbor where ships load or unload.
usage_sentences: The large cargo ship sailed into the port.
Mumbai is a major port city in India.
content.note: A port is a vital maritime hub, a city or town with a harbor facilitating ship loading and unloading. These gateways are crucial for trade, travel, and economic exchange.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Occurring or done after death. (Noun) - An examination of a dead body to determine the cause of death.
usage_sentences: A postmortem examination revealed the cause of death.
The team conducted a postmortem on the failed project to see what went wrong.
content.note: A postmortem is an examination performed after death to ascertain its cause. As an adjective, it describes anything occurring or done following death, revealing insights into events.

content.meaning_en: Cause or arrange for (something) to take place at a later time than that first scheduled.
usage_sentences: They had to postpone the wedding due to unforeseen circumstances.
