The meeting has been postponed until next Friday.
content.note: To postpone is to reschedule an event for a later time than originally planned. This action shifts timelines, often due to unforeseen circumstances or strategic considerations.

content.meaning_en: Safe to drink; drinkable.
usage_sentences: The water from the tap is not potable; you should boil it first.
The hikers carried a filter to make river water potable.
content.note: Potable water is safe for human consumption, meaning it's free from harmful contaminants. Its drinkability is fundamental for health and survival, a critical resource worldwide.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - The actual application or employment of an idea, belief, or method. (Verb) - Repeatedly perform (an activity) or regularly exercise (a skill) in order to improve one's proficiency or facility.
usage_sentences: It takes a lot of practice to become a skilled musician.
She wants to open her own medical practice after she graduates.
content.note: Practice encompasses both the actual application of an idea and the repeated performance of a skill to improve. It bridges theory and mastery, turning knowledge into proficiency.
content.origin: From Old French 'practiser', based on Greek 'praktikos' (concerned with action).

content.meaning_en: Say or estimate that (a specified thing) will happen in the future or will be a consequence of something.
usage_sentences: Weather forecasters predict that it will rain tomorrow.
It is difficult to predict the outcome of the election.
content.note: To predict is to declare or estimate a future event or outcome. It involves forecasting, often based on data, patterns, or intuition, peering into what is yet to unfold.

content.meaning_en: Preconceived opinion that is not based on reason or actual experience.
usage_sentences: We must work to eliminate racial prejudice from our society.
His prejudice against modern art was obvious.
content.note: Prejudice often stems from ignorance or fear, leading to unfair judgments. It's an internal bias acting before factual understanding, not based on reason.

content.meaning_en: Make (something) ready for use or consideration.
usage_sentences: The chef began to prepare the ingredients for the meal.
You need to prepare well for the upcoming exam.
content.note: Preparation is the crucial first step for success. It transforms potential into readiness, ensuring resources are aligned for an upcoming task or event.
content.origin: From Latin 'praeparare', from 'prae-' (in advance) and 'parare' (to make ready).

content.meaning_en: Advise and authorize the use of (a medicine or treatment) for someone.
usage_sentences: The doctor will prescribe antibiotics for your infection.
The law prescribes a specific penalty for that crime.
content.note: While usually medical, "prescribe" can also mean to lay down a rule or course of action. It implies authority and a recommended solution or instruction.
content.origin: From Latin 'praescribere', from 'prae-' (in advance) and 'scribere' (to write).

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A special right, advantage, or immunity granted or available only to a particular person or group of people.
usage_sentences: Access to good education should be a right, not a privilege.
It was a privilege to meet such a distinguished scientist.
content.note: Privilege is unearned advantage, often invisible to those who possess it. Recognizing it is key to understanding societal inequalities and striving for fairness.
content.origin: From Latin 'privilegium', meaning 'law concerning an individual'.

content.meaning_en: Delay or postpone action; put off doing something.
usage_sentences: If you procrastinate, you will have to do all your work at the last minute.
He tends to procrastinate on difficult tasks.
content.note: Procrastination isn't just laziness; it often involves managing difficult emotions. Delaying tasks can create temporary relief but accumulates stress long-term.

content.meaning_en: The action of delaying or postponing something.
usage_sentences: Procrastination is the thief of time.
She overcame her habit of procrastination and became much more productive.
content.note: This noun form highlights the *act itself*. It’s a common human tendency, often fueled by fear of failure or seeking immediate gratification over future reward.
content.origin: From Latin 'procrastinare' (to put off until tomorrow).

content.meaning_en: A high degree of competence or skill; expertise.
usage_sentences: She demonstrated a high level of proficiency in several languages.
The job requires proficiency in computer programming.
content.note: Proficiency signifies mastery achieved through practice and dedication. It's more than just knowing; it's the ability to perform a task effectively and consistently.
content.origin: From 'proficient', from Latin 'proficere' (to advance, make progress).

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - An outline of something, especially a person's face, as seen from one side. (Verb) - Describe (someone or something) in a profile.
usage_sentences: The artist drew a beautiful profile of the woman.
Please create an online profile to apply for the job.
content.note: Beyond a side view, a "profile" can be a summary of characteristics. To "profile" someone can imply creating a descriptive overview, sometimes with biased assumptions.
content.origin: From Italian 'profilo', from 'profilare' (to draw in outline).

content.meaning_en: Information, especially of a biased or misleading nature, used to promote a political cause or point of view.
usage_sentences: The government used propaganda to win support for the war.
It is important to be able to distinguish between news and propaganda.
content.note: Propaganda subtly manipulates public opinion by presenting selective or distorted information. Its power lies in shaping perception, not necessarily truth.
content.origin: From modern Latin 'de propaganda fide' (for propagating the faith), a committee of cardinals.

content.meaning_en: A person regarded as being inspired to speak for God or a god.
usage_sentences: Moses is considered a prophet in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.
The ancient prophet warned the people of impending disaster.
content.note: Prophets are seen as divine messengers, not merely foretellers. Their role is often to guide people towards a moral path or reveal divine will.

content.meaning_en: The action of driving or pushing forward.
usage_sentences: The boat is powered by a jet propulsion system.
He studied different methods of rocket propulsion.
content.note: Propulsion describes the force that moves something, from rockets to ideas. It's the engine of progress, enabling motion and advancement.
content.origin: From late Latin 'propulsio(n-)', from 'propellere' (to drive forward).

content.meaning_en: Concern for one's own area or region at the expense of national unity or wider interests.
usage_sentences: His provincialism prevented him from appreciating the culture of other regions.
The politician was accused of provincialism for focusing only on his home state.
content.note: Provincialism suggests a narrow-mindedness or limited perspective, favoring local customs and concerns over broader, more inclusive viewpoints.

content.meaning_en: An expert or specialist in psychology.
usage_sentences: She decided to see a psychologist to help her deal with stress.
A child psychologist can help children with behavioral problems.
content.note: Psychologists study the human mind and behavior. They diagnose and treat mental, emotional, and behavioral disorders, distinct from psychiatrists who are medical doctors.

content.meaning_en: Having a sharply strong taste or smell.
usage_sentences: The pungent smell of onions and garlic filled the kitchen.
He made a pungent criticism of the government's policies.
content.note: Pungent describes a sharp, often irritating sensory experience. Think of strong cheese, vinegar, or certain spices – it's distinctive and intense.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - (of a cat) make a low continuous vibratory sound expressing contentment. (Noun) - A low continuous vibratory sound expressive of contentment, made by a cat.
usage_sentences: The cat began to purr as she stroked its fur.
The engine of the luxury car had a low, satisfying purr.
content.note: While typically a sign of feline contentment, cats also purr when stressed or injured. It's a complex vocalization with multiple meanings.

content.meaning_en: Follow (someone or something) in order to catch or overtake them.
usage_sentences: The police car had to pursue the speeding vehicle.
She decided to pursue a career in medicine.
content.note: "Pursue" implies persistent effort towards a goal, whether literally chasing or metaphorically seeking an ambition or education. It requires dedication.
content.origin: From Old French 'poursuir', from Latin 'prosequi' (to prosecute).

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who dishonestly claims to have special knowledge and skill in some field, typically medicine.
usage_sentences: The so-called doctor was just a quack selling useless remedies.
He was exposed as a quack by a medical investigation.
content.note: A "quack" is a charlatan, exploiting trust with false claims of expertise, especially in health. This word highlights the danger of deceptive practices.
content.origin: Short for 'quacksalver', from Dutch, probably meaning 'hawker of salve'.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - An animal which has four feet, especially an ungulate mammal.
usage_sentences: Horses, dogs, and elephants are all quadrupeds.
Most land mammals are quadrupeds.
content.note: A quadruped simply means "four-footed." It's a descriptive term for animals like dogs, horses, or cows, emphasizing their mode of locomotion.

content.meaning_en: Reject as invalid, especially by legal procedure.
usage_sentences: The higher court decided to quash the original conviction.
He tried to quash the rumors that were spreading about him.
content.note: To "quash" is to decisively put an end to something, often an idea or a legal ruling. It implies a definitive suppression or annulment.
content.origin: From Old French 'quasser', from Latin 'cassus' (null, void).

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A long or arduous search for something. (Verb) - Search for something.
usage_sentences: The knights went on a quest to find the Holy Grail.
Her quest for knowledge led her to travel the world.
content.note: A quest is more than a simple search; it implies a challenging journey for a significant prize, often involving adventure and overcoming obstacles.
content.origin: From Old French 'queste', from Latin 'quaerere' (to seek).

content.meaning_en: To the utmost or absolute extent or degree; absolutely; completely.
usage_sentences: The movie was quite good, although not the best I've seen.
Are you quite sure you locked the door?
content.note: "Quite" can be confusing. It can mean "completely" (e.g., "quite right") or "to a considerable extent" (e.g., "quite good," implying less than excellent). Context is key.
content.origin: From Old French 'quite', from Latin 'quietus' (at rest).

content.meaning_en: The minimum number of members of an assembly or society that must be present at any of its meetings to make the meeting valid.
usage_sentences: The meeting could not begin because they did not have a quorum.
Once a quorum was present, the committee proceeded to vote.
content.note: A quorum ensures that decisions made are legitimate and representative, preventing a small minority from acting unilaterally in formal settings.
content.origin: From Latin 'quorum', meaning 'of whom', from the wording of commissions for justices of the peace.

content.meaning_en: The emission of energy as electromagnetic waves or as moving particles.
usage_sentences: Exposure to high levels of radiation can be very dangerous.
Radiation therapy is used to treat some types of cancer.
content.note: Radiation is a fundamental way energy travels, from harmless sunlight to powerful X-rays and nuclear emissions. It describes energy dispersal.

content.meaning_en: A medical specialist who uses radioactive substances and X-rays in the diagnosis and treatment of disease.
usage_sentences: The radiologist examined the X-ray to look for a broken bone.
A radiologist interprets medical images like CT scans and MRIs.
content.note: Radiologists are medical detectives, interpreting images like X-rays and MRI scans to diagnose illnesses without invasive procedures.

content.meaning_en: The science dealing with X-rays and other high-energy radiation, especially the use of such radiation for the diagnosis and treatment of disease.
usage_sentences: She is training to be a technician in the hospital's radiology department.
Radiology plays a vital role in modern medicine.
content.note: Radiology is the medical field dedicated to imaging techniques. It's crucial for non-invasive diagnosis, allowing doctors to see inside the body.

content.meaning_en: Smelling or tasting unpleasant as a result of being old and stale.
usage_sentences: The butter had gone rancid after being left out of the fridge.
There was a rancid smell coming from the garbage bin.
content.note: Rancidity is a chemical process, typically oxidation of fats, causing unpleasant odors and flavors. It signals spoilage and inedibility.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A sum of money or other payment demanded or paid for the release of a prisoner. (Verb) - Redeem (a prisoner) for ransom.
usage_sentences: The kidnappers demanded a huge ransom for the safe return of the child.
The family paid the ransom and the hostage was released.
content.note: Ransom describes payment for release, but also the act of liberating someone *by* payment. It highlights a coercive exchange for freedom.
content.origin: From Old French 'rançon', from Latin 'redemptio' (buying back).

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who rises in opposition or armed resistance against an established government or ruler. (Verb) - Rise in opposition or armed resistance to an established government or ruler.
usage_sentences: A group of rebels attacked the army outpost.
As a teenager, he would often rebel against his parents' rules.
content.note: A rebel challenges authority, sometimes violently. The term can imply defiance against unjust systems or merely non-conformity to social norms.

content.meaning_en: A person or thing that receives or is awarded something.
usage_sentences: She was the proud recipient of the employee of the year award.
Please write the name of the recipient on the package.
content.note: The recipient is the passive receiver in an exchange, whether it's a gift, an email, or a benefit. It defines who gains from an action.

content.meaning_en: Avoiding the company of other people; solitary.
usage_sentences: The famous author became reclusive in his later years.
He lived a reclusive life in a small cabin in the mountains.
content.note: A reclusive person deliberately chooses isolation, often for privacy or introspection, rather than being forced into solitude.

content.meaning_en: Put right; correct.
usage_sentences: We need to rectify the error in the financial report.
He apologized and promised to rectify the situation.
content.note: To rectify means to correct a mistake or set something straight. It implies bringing something back to a proper or just state.
content.origin: From late Latin 'rectificare', from 'rectus' (right) and '-ficare' (to make).

content.meaning_en: Contained by or consisting of straight lines.
usage_sentences: The building had a modern, rectilineal design.
A square is a rectilineal figure with four equal sides.
content.note: Rectilineal describes shapes or paths composed purely of straight lines. It emphasizes directness and angularity, contrasting with curves.

content.meaning_en: Occurring often or repeatedly.
usage_sentences: He suffered from recurrent nightmares after the traumatic event.
A recurrent theme in her novels is the search for identity.
content.note: Recurrent implies a pattern of repetition, often of something unwelcome like a disease or a problem. It signals persistence over time.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - An action that is performed as an automatic response to a stimulus and without conscious thought.
usage_sentences: The doctor tested the patient's reflexes by tapping his knee.
Pulling your hand away from a hot object is a reflex action.
content.note: Reflexes are involuntary, rapid responses vital for survival. They bypass conscious processing, demonstrating the body's innate protective mechanisms.

content.meaning_en: The doctrine that reform is the best approach to social and political problems.
usage_sentences: His political philosophy was based on gradual reformism, not revolution.
The party's reformism attracted moderate voters.
content.note: Reformism advocates for gradual, systemic changes within existing structures, believing evolution is better than revolution to solve societal issues.

content.meaning_en: A person who has been forced to leave their country in order to escape war, persecution, or natural disaster.
usage_sentences: Thousands of refugees fled the war-torn country.
The camp was set up to provide shelter for the refugees.
content.note: A refugee is a person displaced by dire circumstances beyond their control. This word emphasizes involuntary displacement and the search for safety.

content.meaning_en: The killing of a king.
usage_sentences: The plot to commit regicide was discovered before it could be carried out.
The execution of King Charles I in England was an act of regicide.
content.note: Regicide is a specific act of murder, not just killing a monarch, but the deliberate assassination of a sovereign. It carries immense political and historical weight.

content.meaning_en: Restore (someone) to health or normal life by training and therapy after imprisonment, addiction, or illness.
usage_sentences: The program helps to rehabilitate prisoners so they can rejoin society.
After the injury, the athlete worked hard to rehabilitate his knee.
content.note: Rehabilitation focuses on holistic restoration—physical, mental, and social—to enable reintegration into a productive life after significant disruption.
content.origin: From medieval Latin 'rehabilitare', from 're-' (again) and 'habilitare' (to make able).

content.meaning_en: Make (someone or something) look or feel younger, fresher, or more lively.
usage_sentences: A week's vacation in the mountains completely rejuvenated him.
The new manager's task is to rejuvenate the struggling company.
content.note: Rejuvenation isn't just about restoring; it's about infusing new energy or youthfulness. It implies revitalization and a renewed vigor.

content.meaning_en: Unwilling and hesitant; disinclined.
usage_sentences: He was reluctant to admit that he had made a mistake.
She seemed reluctant to talk about her past.
content.note: Reluctance isn't outright refusal, but a strong hesitance or unwillingness to act. It signals internal conflict or a lack of enthusiasm.

content.meaning_en: Deep and painful regret for wrongdoing.
usage_sentences: He felt a deep sense of remorse for what he had done.
The defendant showed no remorse for his crimes during the trial.
content.note: Remorse is a powerful, painful emotion recognizing one's own culpability. It's crucial for personal growth and sincere apologies, distinguishing it from simple regret.
content.origin: From Old French 'remors', from Latin 'remordere' (to bite back).

content.meaning_en: Restore (something old, especially a building) to a good state of repair.
usage_sentences: They decided to renovate their old kitchen.
The historic hotel has been beautifully renovated.
content.note: To renovate is to bring old structures back to life, improving their condition and function without necessarily changing their core character.

content.meaning_en: Sincere regret or remorse.
usage_sentences: In his letter, he expressed deep repentance for his actions.
True repentance involves a change in behavior, not just words.
content.note: Repentance is a profound change of heart, more than just feeling sorry. It often involves a commitment to change behavior and seek forgiveness.
content.origin: From Old French 'repentance', from the verb 'repentir'.

content.meaning_en: Restore (a stock or supply) to a former level or condition.
usage_sentences: You need to drink plenty of water to replenish the fluids lost through sweat.
After the party, we had to replenish our stock of food and drinks.
content.note: To replenish means to fill up again, ensuring resources are adequate. It's essential for sustainability and preventing depletion.
content.origin: From Old French 'replenir', meaning 'to fill up again'.

content.meaning_en: An exact copy or model of something, especially one on a smaller scale.
usage_sentences: The museum has a full-scale replica of a dinosaur skeleton.
He built a perfect replica of the famous ship.
content.note: A replica is a faithful imitation. Unlike a forgery, it's openly presented as a copy, often for display or study, not deceit.

content.meaning_en: A class of cold-blooded vertebrate animals that includes tortoises, turtles, snakes, lizards, crocodiles, and alligators.
usage_sentences: Snakes and lizards are both types of reptiles.
Most reptiles lay eggs, though some give birth to live young.
content.note: Reptiles are ectothermic vertebrates, relying on external heat sources. They typically lay eggs and have scales, adapted for diverse environments.

content.meaning_en: Arousing intense distaste or disgust.
usage_sentences: There was a repulsive smell coming from the rotten food.
I find his cruel behavior utterly repulsive.
content.note: Repulsive describes something so offensive it causes an urge to push away or avoid it. It evokes a strong, negative emotional and physical reaction.
content.origin: From late Latin 'repulsivus', from 'repellere' (to drive back).

content.meaning_en: Someone who is slow to reveal emotion or opinions.
usage_sentences: He is a very reserved person and doesn't talk much about himself.
Although she seems like a reserved person at first, she is very friendly.
content.note: A reserved person is often perceived as quiet or private. This trait can be mistaken for shyness, but it often reflects a thoughtful, introspective nature.
content.origin: From the verb 'reserve', from Latin 'reservare' (to keep back).

content.meaning_en: A large natural or artificial lake used as a source of water supply.
usage_sentences: The city gets its drinking water from a large reservoir in the hills.
The reservoir was created by building a dam across the river.
content.note: Reservoirs are crucial for water management, collecting and storing water for human consumption, irrigation, and power generation. They are vital infrastructure.

content.meaning_en: The process of breathing.
usage_sentences: The patient's respiration became slow and shallow.
Cellular respiration is the process by which cells get energy from food.
content.note: Respiration is more than just breathing; it's the physiological exchange of gases (oxygen and carbon dioxide) essential for cellular energy production.

content.meaning_en: Make an attack in return for a similar attack.
usage_sentences: The army promised to retaliate against any further attacks.
She decided not to retaliate, choosing instead to ignore his insults.
content.note: Retaliation highlights a cyclical response, often escalating conflict rather than resolving it. It's a precise reaction, mirroring an initial harmful act.

content.meaning_en: Go back over (the same route that one has just taken).
usage_sentences: He had to retrace his steps to find his lost keys.
The detective asked the witness to retrace her movements on the day of the crime.
content.note: To retrace isn't just physical movement; it's also mentally revisiting steps, arguments, or memories to understand or correct.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Withdraw from enemy forces as a result of their superior power or after a defeat. (Noun) - The act of withdrawing from enemy forces.
usage_sentences: The defeated army was forced to retreat.
She went on a yoga retreat to relax and de-stress.
content.note: A retreat signifies a strategic withdrawal, not always defeat, or a peaceful sanctuary away from pressures. It holds dual meanings of military maneuver and personal haven.
content.origin: From Old French 'retrait', from 'retraire' (to pull back).

content.meaning_en: A scale of numbers used to express the magnitude of earthquakes.
usage_sentences: The earthquake measured 7.8 on the Richter scale.
The Richter scale is logarithmic, so a magnitude 6 earthquake is ten times stronger than a magnitude 5.
content.note: The Richter scale, though often used, is effectively superseded by the moment magnitude scale for large quakes. It's logarithmic; a 7 is ten times stronger than a 6.
content.origin: Named after Charles F. Richter, the American seismologist who developed it.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Subject (someone or something) to contemptuous and dismissive language or behavior. (Noun) - The subjection of someone or something to contemptuous and dismissive language or behavior.
usage_sentences: He was subjected to ridicule for his unusual ideas.
It is unkind to ridicule someone for their mistakes.
content.note: Ridicule is a sharp tool to demean, using contemptuous language or behavior to dismiss individuals or ideas, often causing embarrassment and undermining credibility.

content.meaning_en: Unable to bend or be forced out of shape; not flexible.
usage_sentences: The company has very rigid rules about punctuality.
He maintained a rigid posture throughout the interview.
content.note: Being rigid implies inflexibility, not just physically, but also in thought or rules. It suggests an unwillingness to adapt or compromise.

content.meaning_en: A religious or other solemn ceremony or act.
usage_sentences: The funeral rites were performed according to ancient traditions.
Many cultures have special rites of passage to mark the transition to adulthood.
content.note: Rites are structured, symbolic acts, often spiritual or cultural, marking significant transitions or affirming community values. They provide meaning and structure to life's events.
content.origin: From Latin 'ritus', meaning 'religious observance or ceremony'.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Move with urgent haste. (Noun) - An act of moving with urgent haste.
usage_sentences: He had to rush to catch the last train home.
There's no need to rush; we have plenty of time.
content.note: A rush conveys urgent haste, often leading to overlooked details or impulsive decisions. It can also describe a sudden, overwhelming surge of feeling or activity.
content.origin: From Anglo-Norman French 'russer', related to Old French 'reuser' (to drive back).

content.meaning_en: A long story of heroic achievement, especially a medieval prose narrative in Norse or Icelandic.
usage_sentences: The movie trilogy was an epic saga of good versus evil.
He told us the long saga of his family's journey to America.
content.note: Beyond its medieval Norse roots, 'saga' now describes any sprawling, epic narrative, often involving generations or significant historical events, emphasizing endurance and sweeping scope.
content.origin: From Old Norse, literally 'what is said, a narrative'.

content.meaning_en: The quality of being particularly noticeable or important; prominence.
usage_sentences: The salience of this issue has increased in recent years.
The report highlighted the salience of mental health in the workplace.
content.note: Salience refers to what draws immediate attention or importance, making it stand out from its surroundings. It's about prominence in perception and thought.

content.meaning_en: A place of refuge or safety.
usage_sentences: The wildlife sanctuary protects endangered species.
She sought sanctuary in the church to escape her pursuers.
content.note: A sanctuary offers profound refuge and safety, whether a physical haven or a psychological space, providing protection from external threats or internal turmoil.

content.meaning_en: A sacred place, especially a shrine within a temple or church.
usage_sentences: Only the high priest was allowed to enter the inner sanctum of the temple.
His study was his private sanctum, where he could work without being disturbed.
content.note: A sanctum denotes a highly sacred, often private, and revered space. Unlike a general sanctuary, it implies exclusivity, reserved for rituals or deep contemplation.
content.origin: From Latin, meaning 'holy place', from 'sancire' (to consecrate).

content.meaning_en: The use of irony to mock or convey contempt.
usage_sentences: His voice was full of sarcasm when he complimented my terrible singing.
She has a very dry wit and a talent for sarcasm.
content.note: Sarcasm is irony with an edge, specifically intended to mock, convey contempt, or wound. It often says the opposite of what it means with a sneering tone.

content.meaning_en: The use of humor, irony, exaggeration, or ridicule to expose and criticize people's stupidity or vices.
usage_sentences: The show uses political satire to comment on current events.
Jonathan Swift's 'Gulliver's Travels' is a classic work of satire.
content.note: Satire uses humor, irony, or exaggeration as a sharp tool to expose and critique societal follies or vices, aiming for reform through intelligent mockery.
content.origin: From Latin 'satura (lanx)', meaning '(dish) of mixed fruits'.

content.meaning_en: An action or event regarded as morally or legally wrong and causing general public outrage.
usage_sentences: The politician was forced to resign after a major financial scandal.
The news of the scandal was on the front page of every newspaper.
content.note: A scandal is more than just wrongdoing; it's an action deemed morally or legally objectionable that ignites widespread public outrage and disapproval, often with lasting repercussions.
content.origin: From Greek 'skandalon', meaning 'a cause of offense, a snare'.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who is blamed for the wrongdoings, mistakes, or faults of others. (Verb) - Make a scapegoat of.
usage_sentences: He was made a scapegoat for the company's failures.
The manager tried to scapegoat his assistant to save his own job.
content.note: A scapegoat is unjustly burdened with blame for others' failings, often to deflect responsibility from the true culprits. It’s a tragic act of misdirected blame.
content.origin: From 'scape' (escape) + 'goat', a goat symbolically laden with the sins of the people and sent into the wilderness in the Bible.

content.meaning_en: The state of being scarce or in short supply; shortage.
usage_sentences: There is a scarcity of clean drinking water in the region.
The scarcity of resources led to conflict between the two tribes.
content.note: Scarcity is a core economic principle: desires exceed available resources. It forces choices and creates value, defining the fundamental challenge of resource allocation.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A plan of procedure, listing events and times. (Verb) - Arrange or plan (an event) to take place at a particular time.
usage_sentences: My schedule for next week is already completely full.
The meeting is scheduled for 10 a.m. on Monday.
content.note: A schedule is more than a list; it's a strategic framework for managing time and tasks, critical for coordination, efficiency, and meeting deadlines in any endeavor.
content.origin: From late Latin 'schedula', a diminutive of 'scheda' (papyrus strip).

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - Academic study or achievement; learning of a high level. (Noun) - A grant or payment made to support a student's education, awarded on the basis of academic or other achievement.
usage_sentences: She won a scholarship to study at a prestigious university.
His book is a great work of historical scholarship.
content.note: Scholarship encompasses both deep academic pursuit and the financial aid enabling it. One denotes intellectual endeavor; the other, the opportunity to pursue higher learning.

content.meaning_en: Not connected with religious or spiritual matters.
usage_sentences: India is a secular country, with no official state religion.
She prefers to listen to secular music rather than religious hymns.
content.note: Secular implies separation from religious or spiritual connections, advocating for neutrality in public life and institutions rather than active opposition to faith.
content.origin: From Latin 'saecularis', meaning 'relating to an age or period'.

content.meaning_en: An instrument that measures and records details of earthquakes, such as force and duration.
usage_sentences: The seismograph detected a minor tremor early this morning.
Data from seismographs around the world helps scientists study earthquakes.
content.note: A seismograph precisely measures ground motion during earthquakes, providing crucial data on magnitude, duration, and seismic wave characteristics, vital for understanding Earth's dynamics.

content.meaning_en: The branch of science concerned with earthquakes and related phenomena.
usage_sentences: He is a professor of seismology at the university.
Seismology helps us to understand the forces that shape our planet.
content.note: Seismology is the scientific discipline dedicated to understanding earthquakes, seismic waves, and Earth's internal structure. It deciphers the planet's dynamic geological processes.

content.meaning_en: Take hold of suddenly and forcibly.
usage_sentences: The police will seize the illegal goods.
You have to seize the opportunity when it comes.
content.note: To seize implies a sudden, forceful grasp, whether physically taking an object or mentally grasping an opportunity. It conveys urgency and decisive action.
content.origin: From Old French 'saisir', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: Not often; rarely.
usage_sentences: We seldom see our cousins who live in another country.
He is seldom late for his appointments.
content.note: Seldom conveys infrequency or rarity, highlighting that something occurs only on a few occasions. It's a precise word for events that are not routine.
content.origin: From Old English 'seldan', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A conference or other meeting for discussion or training.
usage_sentences: I attended a seminar on digital marketing last week.
The professor will hold a seminar for graduate students.
content.note: A seminar fosters interactive discussion and focused learning, typically with a smaller group. It emphasizes participation and deeper engagement over passive information reception.

content.meaning_en: Quick to detect or respond to slight changes, signals, or influences.
usage_sentences: My skin is very sensitive to the sun.
You need to be sensitive when discussing this topic.
content.note: Sensitivity implies a keen ability to detect subtle changes or influences. It can be a strength, like empathy, or a vulnerability, like being easily hurt.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Consisting of, forming part of, or taking place in a series. (Noun) - A story or play appearing in regular installments in a magazine or newspaper, or broadcast on television or radio.
usage_sentences: The police are searching for a serial killer.
Charles Dickens' novels were originally published as serials in magazines.
content.note: 'Serial' describes something occurring in a sequence, like a serial publication or a series of events. It contrasts with 'simultaneous' by emphasizing progression over time.

content.meaning_en: The production of raw silk by raising silkworms.
usage_sentences: Sericulture is an important industry in many parts of Asia.
The process of sericulture involves cultivating mulberry leaves for silkworms to eat.
content.note: Sericulture is the ancient and delicate art of cultivating silkworms to produce raw silk. This intricate process was foundational to historical trade routes and luxury goods.

content.meaning_en: A close-fitting cover for something, especially the blade of a knife or sword.
usage_sentences: The warrior drew his sword from its sheath.
The electrician removed the plastic sheath from the wire.
content.note: A sheath is a protective, close-fitting covering, usually for a blade. It highlights the vulnerability of the object and the necessity of its precise protection.
content.origin: From Old English 'scēath', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: Having or showing sharp powers of judgment; astute.
usage_sentences: He was a shrewd businessman who made a fortune in real estate.
She made a shrewd decision to invest in the new company.
content.note: Shrewdness denotes sharp, practical judgment, often characterized by astuteness and cleverness, especially in navigating complex situations or achieving advantageous outcomes.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A form of transport, especially a bus or train, that travels regularly between two places. (Verb) - Travel regularly between two places.
usage_sentences: The hotel provides a free shuttle service to the airport.
The space shuttle was used for many missions into orbit.
content.note: A shuttle describes a regular, systematic back-and-forth movement between two fixed points, whether a vehicle or an object, emphasizing consistent, cyclical transit.
content.origin: From Old English 'scytel', meaning 'dart, missile', related to 'shoot'.

content.meaning_en: A figure of speech involving the comparison of one thing with another thing of a different kind, used to make a description more emphatic or vivid.
usage_sentences: 'As brave as a lion' is a well-known simile.
The poet used a beautiful simile to describe the sunset.
content.note: A simile vividly compares two unlike things using "like" or "as," enhancing description and clarity by drawing unexpected connections, making language more evocative.

content.meaning_en: Occurring or operating at the same time.
usage_sentences: There were several simultaneous attacks on different cities.
The movie will have a simultaneous release in cinemas and on streaming platforms.
content.note: Simultaneous highlights events or actions happening at precisely the same moment. This synchronicity is crucial for coordination, cause-and-effect, and understanding concurrent processes.
content.origin: From medieval Latin 'simultaneus', from 'simul' (at the same time).

content.meaning_en: An internal or external framework of bone, cartilage, or other rigid material supporting or protecting the body of an animal or plant.
usage_sentences: The human skeleton is made up of 206 bones.
Archaeologists unearthed the complete skeleton of a mammoth.
content.note: Beyond its biological role as a body's framework, a skeleton also signifies the essential underlying structure or bare minimum outline of any complex system or idea.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A narrow opening or groove in something. (Verb) - Fit into a slot.
usage_sentences: Please insert your ticket into the slot on the machine.
I've managed to find a slot in my schedule for a meeting.
content.note: A slot is a precise, narrow opening designed for a specific fit, whether a physical component or an allocated time/position. It suggests designated placement and function.
content.origin: From Old French 'esclot', the hollow of the breastbone.

content.meaning_en: The study of the development, structure, and functioning of human society.
usage_sentences: She is studying sociology to understand the causes of social inequality.
Sociology examines how people interact in groups.
content.note: Sociology systematically examines human society, delving into its structures, interactions, and cultural dynamics. It seeks to understand social behavior, institutions, and collective phenomena.

content.meaning_en: The state or situation of being alone.
usage_sentences: He enjoys the peace and solitude of the countryside.
After a busy week, she looked forward to a weekend of solitude.
content.note: Solitude is the chosen state of being alone, often for reflection or peace. It contrasts with loneliness, which implies unwanted isolation and emotional distress.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Able to pay one's debts. (Noun) - The liquid in which a solute is dissolved to form a solution.
usage_sentences: The company managed to remain solvent during the economic crisis.
Water is often called the universal solvent.
content.note: 'Solvent' carries two distinct meanings: financially able to pay debts, or a liquid capable of dissolving another substance. One implies fiscal health, the other, chemical capacity.

content.meaning_en: The forming of a theory or conjecture without firm evidence.
usage_sentences: There has been much speculation in the media about the couple's relationship.
His theory is pure speculation and is not supported by any facts.
content.note: Speculation involves forming theories or making investments based on incomplete evidence, carrying inherent uncertainty. It can drive discovery or financial risk, both without firm guarantees.

content.meaning_en: A person who speaks for a group or organization.
usage_sentences: A spokesman for the company issued a statement to the press.
The government spokesman refused to comment on the matter.
content.note: A spokesman serves as the official voice, articulating the views and policies of an organization or group. Their role demands clear communication and authoritative representation.
content.origin: A compound of 'spoke' (past tense of speak) and 'man'.

content.meaning_en: Plural form of Spokesman.
usage_sentences: Spokespersons from both political parties debated the issue on television.
The company appointed two spokespersons to handle media inquiries.
content.note: 'Spokespersons' is the inclusive plural term for individuals representing a group's official voice, acknowledging gender neutrality while retaining the essence of unified communication.

content.meaning_en: A printed or computer-generated record of the balance in an account.
usage_sentences: I receive a monthly bank statement showing all my transactions.
Please check your credit card statement for any errors.
content.note: A financial statement provides a critical snapshot of an account's balance and transactions. It is indispensable for transparency, auditing, and informed financial decision-making.
content.origin: From the verb 'state', from Latin 'stare' (to stand).

content.meaning_en: Not able to produce children or young.
usage_sentences: The doctor confirmed that the infection had left him sterile.
Surgical instruments must be completely sterile before use.
content.note: Sterile has dual meanings: unable to reproduce, or completely free from living microorganisms. One refers to biological fertility, the other to hygienic purity and absence of life.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who can endure pain or hardship without showing their feelings or complaining. (Adjective) - Enduring hardship without showing feelings or complaining.
usage_sentences: He remained stoic throughout the long and painful ordeal.
She was a true stoic, never complaining despite her illness.
content.note: A stoic endures hardship and pain with remarkable emotional control and resilience, showing neither outward feeling nor complaint. It embodies strength through dispassion.
content.origin: From Greek 'Stōïkos', from 'Stoa (Poikilē)' (Painted Porch), the place in Athens where the philosopher Zeno taught.

content.meaning_en: The endurance of pain or hardship without a display of feelings and without complaint.
usage_sentences: He faced the difficult situation with admirable stoicism.
Stoicism was an ancient Greek school of philosophy.
content.note: Stoicism is a philosophy emphasizing virtue, reason, and resilience. It advocates enduring hardship without complaint, cultivating inner peace by controlling reactions to external events.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - Mental or emotional strain or tension resulting from adverse or demanding circumstances. (Verb) - Subject to stress or tension.
usage_sentences: Working long hours can cause a lot of stress.
The teacher stressed the importance of studying for the exam.
content.note: Stress describes mental or emotional tension, or physical force. It can be a harmful burden or, paradoxically, a beneficial pressure (eustress) that fosters growth.

content.meaning_en: Demanding that rules concerning behavior are obeyed and observed.
usage_sentences: The school has a strict policy against bullying.
Her parents were very strict when she was a child.
content.note: Strict implies rigorous adherence to rules and high expectations, often restricting freedom. It conveys an unwavering demand for obedience and precise observance in conduct or application.

content.meaning_en: Arrange to receive something regularly by paying a subscription.
usage_sentences: I subscribe to several magazines about science and technology.
You can subscribe to our YouTube channel to get notifications for new videos.
content.note: To subscribe means committing to regularly receive content or services, typically through payment. It implies ongoing engagement and a sustained interest beyond a single transaction.

content.meaning_en: (Especially of a change or distinction) so delicate or fine as to be difficult to perceive or describe.
usage_sentences: There was a subtle change in his tone of voice.
The artist is known for her subtle use of color.
content.note: Subtle describes something so delicate or fine it's hard to perceive, demanding keen observation. It often denotes sophistication, nuance, or an understated elegance.
content.origin: From Old French 'soutil', from Latin 'subtilis' (fine, delicate).

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - The act of intentionally causing one's own death. (Verb) - Intentionally cause one's own death.
usage_sentences: The note he left made it clear that his death was a suicide.
Mental health support is crucial in preventing suicide.
content.note: Suicide is the deeply tragic act of intentionally ending one's own life. It signifies profound suffering and encompasses complex psychological, social, and emotional factors.
content.origin: From modern Latin 'suicidium', from 'sui' (of oneself) and '-cidium' (a killing).

content.meaning_en: A brief statement or account of the main points of something.
usage_sentences: Please provide a one-page summary of the report.
In summary, the project was a great success.
content.note: A summary distills complex information to its essence, allowing quick comprehension without losing critical meaning. Focus on conciseness and key ideas.

content.meaning_en: Existing or occurring at or on the surface.
usage_sentences: The doctor said the wound was only superficial and didn't require stitches.
He has only a superficial knowledge of the subject.
content.note: Beyond just surface-level, "superficial" often implies a lack of depth, sincerity, or thoroughness in understanding or engagement.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Of the highest quality or degree. (Noun) - An exaggerated or hyperbolical expression of praise.
usage_sentences: The chef's cooking was of superlative quality.
In grammar, 'best' is the superlative form of 'good'.
content.note: Superlatives denote the absolute extreme, like "best" or "worst." They can also be used hyperbolically, making them potent tools in rhetoric and everyday speech.

content.meaning_en: Involving or denoting a speed greater than that of sound.
usage_sentences: The Concorde was a famous supersonic passenger jet.
The fighter jet created a sonic boom as it flew at supersonic speeds.
content.note: Breaking the sound barrier creates a "sonic boom," a powerful shockwave heard on the ground. Supersonic travel is significantly faster than typical flight.

content.meaning_en: Excessively credulous belief in and reverence for supernatural beings.
usage_sentences: It's a common superstition that breaking a mirror brings seven years of bad luck.
He dismissed her fears as mere superstition.
content.note: Superstitions often link unrelated events, like black cats and bad luck, or knocking on wood for good fortune, revealing a human desire for control or meaning.
content.origin: From Latin 'superstitio(n-)', from 'superstare' (to stand over in awe).

content.meaning_en: The state or condition of being superior to all others in authority, power, or status.
usage_sentences: The company has achieved supremacy in the global market.
The battle was fought to establish naval supremacy.
content.note: Supremacy implies absolute dominance, where one entity holds ultimate power, influence, or control over all others in a given domain.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A sudden large increase, typically temporary. (Verb) - (of a crowd or a natural force) move suddenly and powerfully forward or upward.
usage_sentences: There has been a surge in demand for electric cars.
The crowd surged forward to get a better view.
content.note: A surge is a powerful, often rapid, movement or increase. Think of a power surge overloading a circuit, or a crowd surging forward.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - An amount of something left over when requirements have been met; an excess of production or supply over demand. (Adjective) - More than what is needed or used; excess.
usage_sentences: The country has a trade surplus, exporting more than it imports.
Any surplus food from the event will be donated to charity.
content.note: Surplus signifies having more than enough. It's often desirable in resources but can indicate inefficiency or waste if not managed properly.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Stop resisting to an enemy or opponent and submit to their authority. (Noun) - The action of surrendering.
usage_sentences: The enemy forces were finally forced to surrender.
He refused to surrender his dreams, despite the setbacks.
content.note: Surrender means to yield, not just to an enemy, but also to an emotion or a situation. It can be a strategic move or an act of submission.

content.meaning_en: A weapon with a long metal blade and a hilt with a hand guard, used for thrusting or striking.
usage_sentences: The knight drew his long sword from its scabbard.
The museum displayed a collection of ancient swords.
content.note: Beyond a mere weapon, the sword is a powerful symbol in many cultures, representing honor, justice, power, or even sacrifice.
content.origin: From Old English 'sweord', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A unit of pronunciation having one vowel sound, with or without surrounding consonants, forming the whole or a part of a word.
usage_sentences: The word 'water' has two syllables: 'wa-' and '-ter'.
A haiku is a Japanese poem of three phrases, composed of 5, 7, and 5 syllables.
content.note: Understanding syllables helps with pronunciation, rhythm, and poetry. Each word is built from these fundamental sound units.

content.meaning_en: An instance of a form of reasoning in which a conclusion is drawn from two given or assumed propositions (premises).
usage_sentences: 'All men are mortal; Socrates is a man; therefore, Socrates is mortal' is a famous syllogism.
In logic class, we studied the structure of a valid syllogism.
content.note: A classic syllogism example: All men are mortal. Socrates is a man. Therefore, Socrates is mortal. It's a foundational logical structure.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - (of a substance) made by chemical synthesis, especially to imitate a natural product. (Noun) - A synthetic material or product.
usage_sentences: Nylon and polyester are examples of synthetic fabrics.
The perfume has a synthetic floral scent.
content.note: Synthetic materials are engineered by humans, often designed to replicate or even surpass properties of natural substances, like synthetic diamonds or fabrics.

content.meaning_en: The aquatic larval stage of a frog or toad.
usage_sentences: The children collected tadpoles from the pond in a jar.
A tadpole gradually transforms into a frog through metamorphosis.
content.note: Tadpoles undergo an incredible metamorphosis, transforming from gill-breathing, fish-like larvae into land-dwelling, air-breathing adult amphibians.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A permanent mark or design made on the skin by a process of pricking and inserting indelible pigments. (Verb) - Mark (skin) with tattoos.
usage_sentences: He has a large dragon tattoo on his back.
She decided to get a small tattoo on her wrist.
content.note: Tattoos are ancient art forms, often serving as cultural markers, personal narratives, or aesthetic expressions, permanently etched into the skin.

content.meaning_en: The application of scientific knowledge for practical purposes, especially in industry.
usage_sentences: Modern technology has completely changed the way we live and work.
He is studying information technology at college.
content.note: Technology isn't just gadgets; it's the systematic application of knowledge to create tools, systems, and methods that solve problems and improve life.

content.meaning_en: The supposed communication of thoughts or ideas by means other than the known senses.
usage_sentences: The twins claimed they could communicate through telepathy.
There is no scientific evidence to prove that telepathy exists.
content.note: Telepathy posits a direct mind-to-mind connection, transcending physical barriers. While scientifically unproven, it remains a fascinating concept in fiction.

content.meaning_en: Lasting for only a limited period of time; not permanent.
usage_sentences: He got a temporary job for the summer.
The road closure is only temporary and will be lifted tomorrow.
content.note: Temporary items or situations are transient, reminding us of impermanence. Their short duration often makes them less costly or commitment-heavy.

content.meaning_en: The final point in space or time; the end of something.
usage_sentences: The Grand Central Terminal is a famous railway terminus in New York.
The agreement marked the terminus of the long and difficult negotiations.
content.note: A terminus marks the absolute end, whether it's a train station at the end of a line or the ultimate conclusion of a complex process.

content.meaning_en: Formal statement testifying to someone's character and qualifications, or to the value and quality of goods or services.
usage_sentences: The website was full of glowing testimonials from satisfied customers.
He provided several testimonials from his previous employers.
content.note: Testimonials leverage social proof. They build trust by sharing positive experiences from credible sources, influencing others' decisions.

content.meaning_en: A person who believes in the existence of a god or gods.
usage_sentences: In contrast to an atheist, a theist believes in a higher power.
Her philosophical journey led her from atheism to becoming a theist.
content.note: Theism is a broad category, encompassing monotheistic and polytheistic beliefs. It fundamentally affirms the existence of a divine being or beings.

content.meaning_en: Showing a lack of courage or confidence; easily frightened.
usage_sentences: The timid child was afraid to speak in front of the class.
A timid mouse peeked out from its hole.
content.note: Timid individuals often hesitate, avoiding confrontation or new experiences due to fear. It's a trait that can hinder personal growth.

content.meaning_en: Extremely small.
usage_sentences: The baby had tiny fingers and toes.
I found a tiny crack in the teacup.
content.note: Tiny emphasizes minuteness, often conveying delicacy, precision, or even vulnerability. Think of tiny gears or a tiny kitten.
content.origin: From Middle English, of unknown origin.

content.meaning_en: Poisonous.
usage_sentences: The factory was fined for releasing toxic waste into the river.
Some mushrooms are toxic and should not be eaten.
content.note: Toxic isn't just about physical poison. It also describes harmful relationships, environments, or behaviors that are detrimental to well-being.
content.origin: From late Latin 'toxicus', from Greek 'toxikon (pharmakon)' ([poison] for arrows).

content.meaning_en: A person who betrays a friend, country, principle, etc.
usage_sentences: He was considered a traitor for selling military secrets to the enemy.
Benedict Arnold is a famous traitor in American history.
content.note: A traitor violates trust and loyalty, often with severe consequences. Their actions stem from self-interest, coercion, or ideological shifts.
content.origin: From Old French 'traitour', from Latin 'traditor', from 'tradere' (to hand over).

content.meaning_en: Put (thoughts, speech, or data) into written or printed form.
usage_sentences: She was hired to transcribe the recorded interviews.
The historian's job was to transcribe the ancient manuscript.
content.note: Transcribing converts spoken words or raw data into a readable format. It's crucial for documentation, analysis, and accessibility, such as court records.

content.meaning_en: An apparatus for reducing or increasing the voltage of an alternating current.
usage_sentences: A large transformer is used at the power station to change the voltage.
The electrician had to replace the faulty transformer.
content.note: Transformers are vital in electrical grids, allowing efficient power transmission over long distances by adjusting voltage levels, then reducing them for safe home use.
content.origin: From the verb 'transform', from Latin 'transformare' (to change shape).

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A river or stream flowing into a larger river or lake.
usage_sentences: The Yamuna is a major tributary of the Ganges river.
Several small tributaries feed into the main river.
content.note: Tributaries feed a main river, contributing to its volume and flow. They are crucial components of a river system's hydrology and ecology.

content.meaning_en: Difficult to deal with or do; requiring skill or care.
usage_sentences: It was a tricky question, and he wasn't sure how to answer.
Assembling the new furniture proved to be a tricky task.
content.note: Tricky situations often involve subtle complexities or hidden obstacles. They require careful thought, precise execution, and often a clever approach.

content.meaning_en: Recurring every three years.
usage_sentences: The organization holds a triennial conference for all its members.
It's a triennial event, so the next one will be in 2028.
content.note: Triennial events happen once every three years. It's often used for festivals, conferences, or organizational reviews on a specific cycle.

content.meaning_en: A three-legged stand for supporting a camera or other apparatus.
usage_sentences: He mounted the camera on a tripod to keep it steady.
A tripod is essential for taking long-exposure photographs at night.
content.note: A tripod provides stability, preventing camera shake and enabling long exposures. Its three legs ensure a level base on uneven surfaces.

content.meaning_en: Of little value or importance.
usage_sentences: Don't waste my time with such trivial matters.
They argued over a trivial detail that didn't affect the main plan.
content.note: Trivial things are inconsequential, not worth significant attention or effort. Distinguishing between trivial and important is key for effective focus.
content.origin: From Latin 'trivialis', from 'trivium' (place where three roads meet).

content.meaning_en: A company of dancers, actors, or other entertainers who tour to different venues.
usage_sentences: A troupe of traveling actors performed Shakespeare in the park.
She is a member of a famous dance troupe.
content.note: A troupe is a cohesive group of performers, traveling together to share their art. They embody collaboration and dedicated practice for their audiences.

content.meaning_en: A long high sea wave caused by an earthquake, submarine landslide, or other disturbance.
usage_sentences: The 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami was a devastating natural disaster.
Coastal communities were warned to evacuate due to the tsunami risk.
content.note: Tsunamis are not tidal waves. They are powerful, destructive ocean waves generated by massive displacements of water, often traveling unnoticed across oceans.

content.meaning_en: Two children or animals born at the same birth.
usage_sentences: She gave birth to identical twins, a boy and a girl.
The twins look so much alike that it's hard to tell them apart.
content.note: Identical (monozygotic) twins develop from one fertilized egg that splits, sharing nearly identical DNA. Fraternal (dizygotic) twins come from two separate eggs.

content.meaning_en: A cruel and oppressive ruler.
usage_sentences: The people rose up in rebellion against the tyrant.
He ruled his company like a tyrant, with absolute control.
content.note: A tyrant wields absolute power, but abuses it through oppression, cruelty, and the suppression of dissent, leading to widespread fear and suffering.

content.meaning_en: Relating to or characteristic of all people or things in the world or in a particular group; applicable to all cases.
usage_sentences: Music is often called the universal language.
The desire for happiness is a universal human trait.
content.note: Universal implies applicability across all contexts without exception. A universal truth holds true regardless of culture, time, or location.

content.meaning_en: Impossible to know.
usage_sentences: The exact number of stars in the universe is unknowable.
The future is ultimately unknowable.
content.note: The unknowable represents the limits of human comprehension or available information. Some things are intrinsically beyond our current or future grasp.

content.meaning_en: An upward push or force.
usage_sentences: An object submerged in water experiences an upward force called upthrust.
Geological upthrust created the mountain range over millions of years.
content.note: Upthrust is a fundamental concept in fluid dynamics (buoyancy) and geology (tectonic forces). It's the force that pushes upwards against gravity.

content.meaning_en: The action or practice of lending money at unreasonably high rates of interest.
usage_sentences: Loan sharks are notorious for practicing usury.
Some ancient laws made usury a crime.
content.note: Usury refers specifically to excessive, exploitative interest rates, often considered unethical or illegal, preying on those in desperate need of funds.
content.origin: From Latin 'usura', meaning 'a charge for the use of money'.

content.meaning_en: The state of being useful, profitable, or beneficial.
usage_sentences: This tool has a great deal of utility in the kitchen.
You need to pay your monthly utility bills, like electricity and water.
content.note: Utility defines something's practical worth or effectiveness. In economics, it refers to the satisfaction a consumer gains from a good or service.

content.meaning_en: A low area of land between hills or mountains, typically with a river or stream flowing through it.
usage_sentences: The small village was nestled in a picturesque mountain valley.
A river runs through the bottom of the valley.
content.note: Valleys are often formed by erosion from rivers or glaciers, creating fertile land and natural corridors for human settlement and transport.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who does not eat any food derived from animals and who typically abstains from using other animal products.
usage_sentences: As a strict vegan, she does not eat meat, dairy, or eggs.
The restaurant has a special menu for vegan customers.
content.note: Veganism extends beyond diet; it's a lifestyle aiming to exclude all forms of animal exploitation and cruelty, including animal products in clothing or entertainment.
content.origin: Coined in 1944 by Donald Watson, from the beginning and end of 'vegetarian'.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who does not eat meat, and sometimes other animal products. (Adjective) - Relating to vegetarians or vegetarianism.
usage_sentences: My sister has been a vegetarian for over ten years.
The restaurant offers several delicious vegetarian options.
content.note: Vegetarians abstain from meat, poultry, and fish, but may still consume dairy (lacto-vegetarian), eggs (ovo-vegetarian), or both (lacto-ovo vegetarian).

content.meaning_en: Regard with great respect; revere.
usage_sentences: The local people venerate their ancestors with annual ceremonies.
She is a writer who is venerated by her readers.
content.note: To venerate is to deeply honor and show profound respect, often associated with religious figures, revered ancestors, or sacred traditions.

content.meaning_en: Seeking to harm someone in return for perceived injury.
usage_sentences: He had a vengeful look in his eyes after being betrayed.
She was too kind to be a vengeful person.
content.note: Vengeful actions are driven by a desire for retribution, often fueled by anger and a sense of injustice, perpetuating cycles of conflict.
content.origin: From 'vengeance', from Old French 'vengeance', from 'venger' (to avenge).

content.meaning_en: The quality of using more words than needed; wordiness.
usage_sentences: The report was criticized for its unnecessary verbosity.
His verbosity made his speeches long and boring.
content.note: Verbosity hinders clarity and efficiency. Conciseness is valued, as using fewer words to convey the same meaning often indicates stronger communication.

content.meaning_en: A decision on a disputed issue in a civil or criminal case or an inquest.
usage_sentences: The jury returned a verdict of guilty.
The public is waiting for the final verdict in the high-profile case.
content.note: A verdict is the jury's (or judge's) definitive finding, crucial in legal proceedings. It declares guilt, innocence, or liability after deliberation.
content.origin: From Anglo-Norman French 'verdit', from Old French 'voir' (true) and 'dit' (saying).

content.meaning_en: Able to adapt or be adapted to many different functions or activities.
usage_sentences: He is a versatile actor who is equally good in comedy and drama.
A smartphone is a very versatile device with many different functions.
content.note: Versatile individuals or tools are highly adaptable, capable of performing diverse tasks effectively. This trait is highly valued in many fields.

content.meaning_en: An animal of a large group distinguished by the possession of a backbone or spinal column.
usage_sentences: Mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, and fishes are all vertebrates.
The evolution of vertebrates was a major step in the history of life.
content.note: Vertebrates include fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals. This defining skeletal feature allows for greater size, mobility, and complexity.

content.meaning_en: A character whose evil actions or motives are important to the plot.
usage_sentences: In every good story, the hero must defeat the villain.
He was cast as the villain in the new action movie.
content.note: A villain often reveals society's dark reflections, compelling us to confront uncomfortable truths within narratives.
content.origin: From Old French 'vilein', originally meaning 'peasant' or 'farm worker'.

content.meaning_en: Behavior showing high moral standards.
usage_sentences: Patience is a virtue that not everyone possesses.
He was a man of great virtue and integrity.
content.note: Virtue embodies admirable moral character, yet its definition often shifts with cultural perspectives and personal values.
content.origin: From Latin 'virtus', meaning 'valor, merit, moral perfection'.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Thinking about or planning the future with imagination or wisdom. (Noun) - A person with original ideas about what the future will or could be like.
usage_sentences: Steve Jobs was a visionary who revolutionized the technology industry.
The architect had a visionary plan to redesign the city center.
content.note: A visionary person or plan looks far beyond the present, conceiving innovative futures rather than merely reacting to now.

content.meaning_en: Liable to change rapidly and unpredictably, especially for the worse.
usage_sentences: The political situation in the country is highly volatile.
Gasoline is a volatile substance that evaporates quickly.
content.note: Volatile describes something highly unstable, prone to rapid, often negative, change, from markets to temperaments.

content.meaning_en: Done, given, or acting of one's own free will.
usage_sentences: Attendance at the workshop is completely voluntary.
She makes a voluntary contribution to the charity every month.
content.note: Voluntary actions stem from one's own free will, distinguishing them from coerced or obligatory undertakings.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who freely offers to take part in an enterprise or undertake a task. (Verb) - Freely offer to do something.
usage_sentences: The organization is looking for a volunteer to help with fundraising.
He volunteered to coach the children's football team.
content.note: A volunteer offers their time or skills without expectation of payment, demonstrating altruism and community spirit.

content.meaning_en: Susceptible to physical or emotional attack or harm.
usage_sentences: Young children are especially vulnerable to illness.
The new computer system is vulnerable to cyber attacks.
content.note: Vulnerable implies an exposed state, susceptible to harm or influence, whether physically, emotionally, or systemically.

content.meaning_en: Walk or move in a leisurely, rambling way.
usage_sentences: We spent the afternoon wandering through the streets of the old town.
His mind began to wander during the long lecture.
content.note: To wander is to move without a fixed destination, embracing the journey itself rather than focusing on arrival.
content.origin: From Old English 'wandrian', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A document issued by a legal or government official authorizing the police or some other body to make an arrest, search premises, or carry out some other action.
usage_sentences: The police had a warrant to search the suspect's house.
His strange behavior warrants further investigation.
content.note: A warrant is a critical legal document, authorizing specific official actions, ensuring procedural due process.
content.origin: From Old Northern French 'warant', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A cascade of water falling from a height, formed when a river or stream flows over a precipice or steep incline.
usage_sentences: We hiked through the forest to see the spectacular waterfall.
The sound of the waterfall was deafening.
content.note: Waterfalls are natural spectacles where rivers dramatically plunge, showcasing raw geological power and beauty.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Speak very softly using one's breath without vibration of the vocal cords, especially for secrecy. (Noun) - A soft, quiet, or hushed sound.
usage_sentences: She leaned over to whisper a secret in his ear.
They spoke in whispers so as not to wake the baby.
content.note: Whispering allows for private communication or a subtle sound, conveying secrets or intimacy with hushed tones.
content.origin: From Old English 'hwisprian', of imitative origin.

content.meaning_en: A person or company that sells goods in large quantities at low prices, typically to retailers.
usage_sentences: The shop buys its products directly from the wholesaler.
A wholesaler acts as a middleman between the manufacturer and the retailer.
content.note: A wholesaler operates behind the retail storefront, supplying goods in bulk, forming a crucial link in the supply chain.

content.meaning_en: A woman who has lost her husband by death and has not married again.
usage_sentences: She became a widow at a young age when her husband died in the war.
The charity provides support for widows and their children.
content.note: A widow navigates life after losing her husband, a significant status change reflecting personal bereavement and societal roles.
content.origin: From Old English 'widewe', of Indo-European origin.

content.meaning_en: A man who has lost his wife by death and has not married again.
usage_sentences: He has been a widower for many years but has never remarried.
The old widower was very lonely after his wife passed away.
content.note: A widower experiences the profound loss of his wife, facing grief and adjusting to life as a single man.

content.meaning_en: Intentionally or deliberately.
usage_sentences: He wilfully ignored the instructions and did it his own way.
She was accused of wilfully damaging the property.
content.note: To act wilfully means deliberately, often with an intent that is stubborn, mischievous, or even malicious.
content.origin: From the adjective 'wilful', a compound of 'will' and '-ful'.

content.meaning_en: Become less intense or severe; subside; decrease.
content.meaning_hi: कम प्रभावी हो जाना; कम होना; घटना
usage_sentences: After a few hours, the storm began to abate, and the winds calmed down.
The medicine should help to abate the pain from your headache.
content.note: Abate signifies a decrease in intensity or severity, like a storm finally subsiding or a fever breaking.
content.origin: From Old French 'abatre' meaning 'to beat down', from Latin 'battuere' (to beat).

content.meaning_en: A slaughterhouse; a place where animals are killed for food.
usage_sentences: The meat processing plant included a large, modern abattoir.
Regulations ensure that abattoirs maintain high standards of hygiene.
content.note: An abattoir is a slaughterhouse, a facility for processing animals into food, often a site of ethical debate.

content.meaning_en: The head or superior of an abbey or monastery for men.
usage_sentences: The abbot was responsible for the spiritual and administrative well-being of the monastery.
Brother Thomas was elected as the new abbot by the monks.
content.note: An abbot holds spiritual and administrative authority over a monastery, guiding its monks and managing its affairs.
content.origin: From late Latin 'abbas', from Greek, based on Aramaic 'abba' meaning 'father'.

content.meaning_en: To give up a position of power, right, or throne, especially voluntarily.
usage_sentences: King Edward VIII had to abdicate the throne to marry the woman he loved.
The CEO decided to abdicate his position after the company's poor performance.
content.note: To abdicate is to formally give up a high office or throne, a momentous act of relinquishment, often voluntary.

content.meaning_en: A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically an unwelcome one.
content.meaning_hi: पथ से भटक जाना; सामान्य से विचलन
usage_sentences: The single poor grade on his report card was an aberration from his usual high marks.
Her sudden outburst of anger was an aberration that surprised everyone.
content.note: An aberration is a deviation from the normal or expected, often hinting at an anomaly or an unwelcome departure.

content.meaning_en: The act of washing oneself, often as a religious rite.
usage_sentences: Before entering the temple, the pilgrims performed their ritual ablutions.
His morning routine included a quick ablution and prayer.
content.note: Ablution refers to ceremonial washing, often performed for ritual purification, particularly in religious traditions.

content.meaning_en: To renounce or reject something desired or valuable; to deny oneself things.
usage_sentences: The monk chose to abnegate all worldly pleasures for a life of spiritual devotion.
She had to abnegate her personal ambitions to care for her family.
content.note: To abnegate is to renounce or deny oneself something desirable, often for a higher principle or self-discipline.

content.meaning_en: To formally put an end to a system, practice, or institution.
usage_sentences: The new law aims to abolish child labor completely.
Abraham Lincoln is famous for his role in abolishing slavery in the United States.
content.note: To abolish is to formally and completely put an end to something, especially a system, practice, or institution.

content.meaning_en: The original inhabitants of a country or region.
usage_sentences: The culture of the Australian Aborigines is one of the oldest in the world.
The rights of the aborigines were discussed at the international conference.
content.note: Aborigines are the indigenous peoples of a land, the original inhabitants present since ancient times.
content.origin: From Latin 'ab origine', meaning 'from the beginning'.

content.meaning_en: To shorten a piece of writing (book, speech, etc.) without losing the essential meaning.
usage_sentences: The publisher decided to abridge the classic novel to make it more accessible to young readers.
He had to abridge his speech to fit the ten-minute time limit.
content.note: To abridge is to shorten text while preserving its core meaning, creating a concise summary, not just a truncation.
content.origin: From Old French 'abregier', from Latin 'abbreviare' (to shorten).

content.meaning_en: To repeal or do away with (a law, right, or formal agreement).
usage_sentences: The parliament voted to abrogate the unpopular tax law.
A new treaty was signed to abrogate all previous agreements.
content.note: To abrogate is to repeal or do away with a law, right, or formal agreement, often by an authoritative act.

content.meaning_en: To leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to escape from custody or avoid arrest.
usage_sentences: The cashier was caught on video as he tried to abscond with the day's earnings.
The prisoner managed to abscond from the minimum-security facility.
content.note: To abscond is to flee secretly and hurriedly, typically to escape legal repercussions or financial obligations.

content.meaning_en: Formal release from guilt, obligation, or punishment; forgiveness, especially in a religious context.
usage_sentences: After his confession, the priest granted him absolution.
The new evidence led to her complete absolution from all charges.
content.note: Absolution grants formal forgiveness or release from guilt, often a sacred act conveying spiritual pardon.

content.meaning_en: Difficult to understand; obscure; perplexing.
usage_sentences: The professor's lecture on philosophy was too abstruse for me to follow.
He delved into abstruse theories that few could comprehend.
content.note: Abstruse describes ideas or texts that are complex and difficult to comprehend, requiring deep intellectual effort.

content.meaning_en: Wildly unreasonable, illogical, or inappropriate; ridiculous.
usage_sentences: The suggestion that we could finish the project in one day was completely absurd.
She has a wonderfully absurd sense of humor.
content.note: Absurd denotes something wildly unreasonable or illogical, often evoking a sense of ridiculousness or incongruity.

content.meaning_en: To make more noticeable or prominent; emphasize.
usage_sentences: The new haircut seemed to accentuate her high cheekbones.
The report should accentuate the positive outcomes of the research.
content.note: To accentuate is to make something more prominent or noticeable, drawing attention and emphasis to it.

content.meaning_en: An award or privilege granted as a special honour or as an acknowledgement of merit.
usage_sentences: Receiving the Nobel Prize is the highest accolade a scientist can achieve.
The film received numerous accolades from critics.
content.note: An accolade is a prestigious award, honor, or praise given in recognition of merit or achievement.
content.origin: From French, literally 'an embrace', from Latin 'ad' (to) + 'collum' (neck).

content.meaning_en: A person who helps another commit a crime or wrongdoing.
usage_sentences: The driver of the getaway car was charged as an accomplice to the bank robbery.
She denied being an accomplice, claiming she knew nothing of the plan.
